Maharastra Tourism

Plan your trip.

Page no: 1/4

Favourite Places :

Forts:

The forts in Maharashtra were constructed from the point at which some of the early ruling dynasties (and their vassals) held power, such as the Satvahanas, the Rashtrakutas, the Kadambas, the Chalukyas, the Yadavas, the Afghans, the Bahmanis, the Gonds in Berar, the sultanates of Ahmednagar, Bijapur and Berar, the Siddis, the Europeans (British, Portuguese), and last but not the least the Marathas. The Marathas gave tremendous importance to forts as they were their strongest defence against marauding invaders. Due to the inherent hilly terrain of the Sahyadri range, most of their forts belonged to the 'hill' category. These forts protected the army and the wealth of the kings and housed virtually an entire village inside the fort.

Beaches:

A beach is a landform alongside a body of water which consists of loose particles. The particles composing a beach are typically made from rock, such as sand, gravel, shingle, pebbles, etc., or biological sources, such as mollusc shells or coralline algae. Sediments settle in different densities and structures, depending on the local wave action and weather, creating different textures, colors and gradients or layers of material. Though some beaches form on inland freshwater locations such as lakes and rivers, most beaches are in coastal areas where wave or current action deposits and reworks sediments. Erosion and changing of beach geologies happens through natural processes, like wave action and extreme weather events. Where wind conditions are correct, beaches can be backed by coastal dunes which offer protection and regeneration for the beach.

Spiritual Places:

A pilgrimage is a journey or quest for moral or spiritual significance. Many religions attach spiritual significance to certain locations. These locations are deemed holy because of mythical or theological beliefs associated with them. India is certainly a holy land, filled with pilgrimage sites such as temples, beautiful churches, serene monasteries, mosques, and majestic gurudwaras.

Wildlife Destinations:

Wildlife refers to undomesticated animal species, but has come to include all organisms that grow or live wild in an area without being introduced by humans. Wildlife was also synonymous to game: those birds and mammals that were hunted for sport. Wildlife can be found in all ecosystems. Deserts, plains, grasslands, woodlands, forests, and other areas including the most developed urban areas, all have distinct forms of wildlife. While the term in popular culture usually refers to animals that are untouched by human factors, most scientists agree that much wildlife is affected by human activities. Some wildlife threaten human safety, health, property and quality of life. However, many wild animals, even the dangerous ones, have value to human beings. This value might be economic, educational, or emotional in nature.

Hill Stations:

A hill station is a town located at a higher elevation than the nearby plain or valley. The English term was originally used mostly in colonial Asia, but also in Africa (albeit rarely), for towns founded by European colonialists as refuges from the summer heat and, as Dale Kennedy observes about the Indian context, "the hill station was seen as an exclusive British preserve: here it was possible to render the Indian into an outsider".The term is still used in present day, particularly in India, which has the largest number of hill stations, most are situated at an altitude of approximately 1,000 to 2,500 metres (3,300 to 8,200 ft).

WaterFalls:

Waterfalls are sometimes interchangeably referred to as "cascades" and "cataracts", though some sources specify a cataract as being a larger and more powerful waterfall and a cascade as being smaller. A plunge pool is a type of stream pool formed at the bottom of a waterfall. A waterfall may also be referred to as a "foss" or "force". A waterfall is any point in a river or stream where water flows over a vertical drop or a series of steep drops. Waterfalls also occur where meltwater drops over the edge of a tabular iceberg or ice shelf.

Caves:

A cave or cavern is a natural void under the Earth's surface. Caves often form by the weathering of rock and often extend deep underground. Exogene caves are smaller openings that extend a relatively short distance underground (such as rock shelters). Caves which extend further underground than the opening is wide are called endogene caves. Speleology is the science of exploration and study of all aspects of caves and the cave environment. Visiting or exploring caves for recreation may be called caving, potholing, or spelunking.

Monuments :

A monument is a type of structure that was explicitly created to commemorate a person or event, or which has become relevant to a social group as a part of their remembrance of historic times or cultural heritage, due to its artistic, historical, political, technical or architectural importance. Examples of monuments include statues, (war) memorials, historical buildings, archaeological sites, and cultural assets. If there is a public interest in its preservation, a monument can for example be listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Cultural Heritage and Conflict gives the next definition of monument: Monuments result from social practices of construction or conservation of material artifacts through which the ideology of their promoters is manifested. The concept of the modern monument emerged with the development of capital and the nation-state in the fifteenth century when the ruling classes began to build and conserve what were termed monuments.

Other Places To Visit :

Travel is the movement of people between distant geographical locations. Travel can be done by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, ship or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip. Travel can also include relatively short stays between successive movements, as in the case of tourism. Travel in the Middle Ages offered hardships and challenges, though it was important to the economy and to society. The wholesale sector depended (for example) on merchants dealing with/through caravans or sea-voyagers, end-user retailing often demanded the services of many itinerant peddlers wandering from village to hamlet, gyrovagues (wandering monks) and wandering friars brought theology and pastoral support to neglected areas, traveling minstrels toured, and armies ranged far and wide in various crusades and in sundry other wars. Pilgrimages were common in both the European and Islamic world and involved streams of travelers both locally and internationally.

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Raigad

Raigad Fort, located in Maharashtra, India, is a historic hill fortress that served as the capital of the Maratha Empire under Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj's rule. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location:
Raigad District, Maharashtra, India
Places to Visit:
  • Raigad Fort: Main attraction, offering breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape
  • Shivaji Maharaj's Samadhi (Tomb): Memorial of the Maratha king
  • Jagdishwar Temple: Ancient Shiva temple
  • Queen's Chamber (Rani Vasa): Royal residence
  • Takmak Tok: Cliff point offering stunning views
  • Hirkani Buruj: Historic cannon placement

Things to Do:
  • Trekking: Hike up to the fort (approx. 1.5 hours)
  • Ropeway: Take a cable car ride to the top (alternative to trekking)
  • Historical exploration: Explore the fort's architecture, ruins, and museums
  • Scenic views: Enjoy panoramic views of the Sahyadri Mountains
  • Local cuisine: Try traditional Maharashtrian food

Tips and Essentials:
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February (cool climate)
  • Timings: 9 am to 5 pm
  • Entrance Fee: ₹50 (approx.)
  • Guide Services: Available for hire
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient water and snacks; local eateries available
  • Footwear: Wear comfortable shoes for trekking
  • Safety: Follow instructions from local guides and authorities

Festivals and Events:
  • Shivaji Jayanti (February/March): Celebrates Chhatrapati Shivaji's birth anniversary
  • Raigad Festival (November/December): Cultural and historical festivities

How to Reach:
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Mumbai (160 km) or Pune (145 km)
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Veer (60 km) or Mangaon (65 km)
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities

Detailed View:

Previous Next

Shivneri Fort

Shivneri Fort is a fascinating destination for history buffs and adventure seekers alike! Located near Junnar in Pune district, Maharashtra, this ancient military fortification is the birthplace of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, the founder of the Maratha Empire.

Getting There
To reach Shivneri Fort, you can take a bus or drive from Pune, which is about 105 kilometres away.The fort is situated near Junnar town, and there are two main roads leading to it: Sakhali Road and the route through Seven Doors.
Places to Explore
Inside the fort, you'll find several interesting spots, including:
  • Temple of Goddess Shivai: A beautiful temple dedicated to the goddess, with six to seven caves behind it.
  • Ambarkhana: A historic storage facility for food grains, which has undergone significant damage over time.
  • Water Tanks: Several water tanks, such as Ganga and Yamuna, are scattered throughout the fort.
  • Shivkunj: A memorial dedicated to Shivaji Maharaj, built in his honour.

Things to Keep in Mind
Before planning your visit, remember:
  • The fort is surrounded by steep slopes, making it challenging to climb.
  • There are two routes to the fort: one via Sakhali Road and the other through Seven Doors.
  • The climb can take around 1.5 to 2 hours, depending on the route you take.

Nearby Attractions
If you're interested in exploring more, consider visiting:
  • Lenyadri Caves: A stunning cave complex located near Junnar.
  • Shree Vighnahar Ganpati Temple: A beautiful temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha.
  • Manikdoh Dam: A scenic dam located near Junnar.

How to Reach:
  • From Pune: 90 km (56 miles), 2-hour drive via NH60.
  • From Mumbai: 160 km (99 miles), 4-hour drive via NH4.
  • From Junnar: 2 km (1.2 miles), 10-minute drive.
  • By Public Transport:
  • Bus: Regular ST buses from Pune, Mumbai, and Junnar.
  • Train: Nearest railway station is Pune (90 km) or Kalyan (120 km).

Detailed View:

Previous Next

Singhgad Fort

Sinhagad Fort is an ancient hill fortress located about 49 km southwest of Pune, India. This historic site is a must-visit for its stunning architecture, breathtaking views, and rich history.

History
The fort has witnessed many battles, most notably the Battle of Sinhagad in 1670, and was previously known as Kondhana . It was built around 2000 years ago and was strategically located to provide natural protection from enemies due to its steep slopes
Places to Explore
Some popular attractions within the fort include:
  • Temple of Goddess Shivai: A beautiful temple dedicated to the goddess, with six to seven caves behind it.
  • Ambarkhana: A historic storage facility for food grains, which has undergone significant damage over time.
  • Water Tanks: Several water tanks, such as Ganga and Yamuna, are scattered throughout the fort.
  • Shivkunj: A memorial dedicated to Shivaji Maharaj, built in his honour.

Things to do
Visitors can enjoy:
  • Trekking: A 2.7 km trek from the base to the top of the fort
  • There are two routes to the fort: one via Sakhali Road and the other through Seven Doors.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views of the surrounding landscape

How to Reach:
  • By Road:
  • From Pune: 30 km (19 miles), 1-hour drive via NH4.
  • From Mumbai: 180 km (112 miles), 4-hour drive via NH4.
  • By Public Transport:
  • Bus: Regular ST buses from Pune (Swargate, Shivaji Nagar).
  • Shared Jeep/ Autorickshaw: Available from Pune.

Detailed View:

Previous Next

Torna Fort

Torna Fort, also known as Prachandagad, is a must-visit destination for history buffs and adventure seekers! Located in the Pune district of Maharashtra, India, this ancient hill fortress stands tall at 1,403 meters above sea level, making it the highest hill-fort in the district .

History
Torna Fort has a rich history, dating back to the 13th century when it was constructed by the Shiva Panth. In 1646, Shivaji Maharaj captured the fort at just 16 years old, marking the beginning of the Maratha Empire. The fort changed hands several times, with the Mughal Empire briefly gaining control in the 18th century.
Places to Explore
Within the fort, you'll find several exciting spots, including:
  • Menghai Devi Temple, also known as the Tornaji temple, situated near the entrance
  • udhla Machi, a massive structure with a unique shape resembling an oil container
  • WZunjar Machi, offering breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape
  • Water Tanks, such as Khokad taaki.

Things to Do
Torna Fort offers a range of activities, including:
  • Trekking: A challenging 2-3 hour trek to the top, with stunning views of the surrounding landscape
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture
  • Photography: Capture the breathtaking views and scenic beauty of the fort

Tips and Essentials
  • Best time to visit: September to March, avoiding the rainy season
  • Entry fee: Free
  • Difficulty level: Challenging

How to Reach:
  • By Road:
  • From Pune: 55 km (34 miles), 1.5-hour drive via NH4.
  • From Mumbai: 200 km (124 miles), 4.5-hour drive via NH4.
  • By Public Transport:
  • Bus: Regular ST buses from Pune (Swargate, Shivaji Nagar) to Velhe village.
  • Shared Jeep/Autorickshaw: Available from Velhe village to Torna Fort.

Detailed View:

Previous Next

Harishchandra Fort

Harishchandragad Fort is a popular trekking and tourism destination in Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location
Ahmednagar district, Maharashtra, India
Places to Explore
  • Harishchandreshwar Temple: Ancient Shiva temple
  • Konkan Kada: Cliff offering breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape
  • Taramati Peak: Highest point on the fort
  • Nali Chi Vaat: Narrow pass with stunning views.

Things to Do:
  • Trekking: Explore the fort's scenic trails
  • Camping: Overnight stays allowed with permission
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets

Tips and Essentials:
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.)
  • Trekking Difficulty: Easy to challenging

How to Reach:
  • By Road:
  • From Mumbai: 160 km (99 miles), 4-hour drive via NH4.
  • From Pune: 140 km (87 miles), 3.5-hour drive via NH4.
  • By Public Transport:
  • Bus: Regular ST buses from Mumbai, Pune, and Ahmednagar to Khireswar or Rajur villages.
  • Shared Jeep/Autorickshaw: Available from Khireswar or Rajur villages.

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Pratapgad

Pratapgad Fort is an amazing destination for history buffs and nature lovers alike! Located in the Satara district of Maharashtra, it's about 24 kilometres from the popular Mahabaleshwar hill station.

History and Significance
This magnificent fort was built by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj in 1656 to defend the banks of the Nira and Koyna rivers. It's famously known for the Battle of Pratapgad, where Shivaji Maharaj defeated Afzal Khan, a general of the Bijapur Sultanate, in 1659.
Places to Explore
When you visit Pratapgad Fort, be sure to check out:
  • Tulja Bhawani Temple: A historic temple built by Shivaji Maharaj, featuring a majestic eight-handed goddess Bhawani idol.
  • Afzal Khan's Tomb: A significant historical landmark marking the site of Afzal Khan's defeat.
  • Bhavani Mata Mandir: A beautiful temple where Shivaji Maharaj is believed to have received the sacred Bhavani Talwar.
  • Statue of Shivaji Maharaj: An impressive bronze equestrian statue, unveiled by Jawaharlal Nehru in 1957.

Things to Do
Pratapgad Fort offers plenty of activities for visitors:
  • Trekking: Take a moderately easy trek to the top of the fort, with approximately 450 steps.
  • Camping: Set up your tents near the Mahadev temple, but be sure to carry sufficient water and food.
  • Photography: Capture breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape and historic architecture.
  • Guided Tours: Join a guided tour to explore the fort's 12 notable sights, available for around ₹300.

Tips and Essentials
  • Best time to visit: Throughout the year, but avoid heavy rainfall.
  • Distance from Mahabaleshwar: 22 kilometres.
  • Transportation: Regular bus services and taxis available from Mahabaleshwar.
  • Accommodation: Options range from camping to hotels and resorts in Mahabaleshwar.

How to Reach:
  • From Mumbai: 210 km (130 miles), 4.5-hour drive via NH4.
  • From Pune: 140 km (87 miles), 3.5-hour drive via NH4.
  • From Satara: 45 km (28 miles), 1-hour drive.
  • By Public Transport
  • Bus: Regular ST buses from Mumbai, Pune, and Satara to Mahabaleshwar/Pratapgad.
  • Shared Jeep/Autorickshaw: Available from Mahabaleshwar.

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Murud janjira

Murud-Janjira Fort is a majestic 15th-century sea fort located off the coast of Murud in Raigad District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

History
Built by the Siddi dynasty in 1489, Murud-Janjira Fort was a strategic naval base and trading centre. It withstood numerous attacks from the Portuguese, British, and Marathas.
Places to Explore
  • Main Entrance: The fort's imposing entrance, flanked by two stone towers.
  • Rajpuri Lighthouse: Offers stunning views of the surrounding waters.
  • Shah Peers Mosque: A beautiful mosque built by the Siddi rulers.
  • Janjira Caves: Ancient caves with intricate carvings.
  • Water Tanks: Large water storage systems.

Things to Do
  • Boat Ride: Take a 15-20 minute boat ride from Murud Jetty to the fort.
  • Guided Tours: Join a guided tour to explore the fort's history and architecture.
  • Snorkelling and Scuba Diving: Explore the surrounding coral reefs.
  • Beach Activities: Enjoy the nearby beaches, such as Murud Beach.

Tips and Essentials
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February.
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.).
  • Boat Timings: 7 am to 5 pm.
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies.
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts in Murud.

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during monsoons or rough seas.
  • Sea Conditions: Be cautious of strong currents and tidal waves.
  • Respect Local Regulations: Follow guidelines to preserve the fort's historical significance.

Nearby Attractions
  • Murud Beach: Famous for its pristine waters and water sports.
  • Kashid Beach: A scenic beach with crystal-clear waters.
  • Raigad Fort: A historic hill fort and former capital of the Maratha Empire.

How to Reach
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Mumbai (140 km).
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Roha (45 km).
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai and Pune.

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Purandar Fort

Purandar Fort is a majestic historical destination in Maharashtra, India, perfect for trekking and exploration. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location:
Purandar, Pune district, Maharashtra, India
History:
Built in the 14th century by the Bahmani Sultanate, the fort was later captured by Shivaji Maharaj in 1646. It played a significant role in the Maratha Empire's expansion.
Places to Explore:
  • Purandar Fort: The main attraction, with impressive architecture and scenic views.
  • Bapurao Deshpande Museum: Showcasing the history and artifacts of the fort.
  • Shivaji Maharaj's Birthplace: A memorial marking the birthplace of Shivaji Maharaj.
  • Dilli Darwaja: The main entrance gate.
  • Mahadev Temple: An ancient Shiva temple.

Trekking Routes:
  • Easy Route: From the base village, Narayanpur (4-5 km, 1-2 hours).
  • Moderate Route: From the village of Saswad (6-7 km, 2-3 hours).

Things to Do:
  • Trekking: Explore the fort's scenic trails.
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets.
  • Camping: Overnight stays allowed with permission.

Tips and Essentials:
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February.
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.).
  • Trekking Difficulty: Easy to moderate.
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies.
  • Accommodation: Basic facilities available, including government rest houses.

Safety Precautions:
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat.
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear.
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife.

How to Reach:
  • From Pune: 45 km (28 miles), 1.5-hour drive via NH4.
  • From Mumbai: 200 km (124 miles), 4.5-hour drive via NH4.
  • From Satara: 120 km (75 miles), 3-hour drive.
  • By Public Transport:
  • Bus: Regular ST buses from Pune (Swargate, Shivaji Nagar) to Saswad.
  • Shared Jeep/Autorickshaw: Available from Saswad to Purandar Fort.

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Lohagad Fort

Lohagad Fort is a popular trekking and tourism destination in Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location:
Lohagad Fort, Lonavala, Pune District, Maharashtra, India
History:
Built in the 18th century by the Marathas, Lohagad Fort was used to keep an eye on the surrounding region.
Places to Explore:
  • Ganesh Darwaja: Main entrance gate
  • Trimbakeshwar Mahadev Temple: Ancient Shiva temple
  • Vinchu Kata: A scenic viewpoint
  • Lohagadwadi: Base village with historic significance
  • Scenic Viewpoints: Panoramic views of the Sahyadri Mountains

Trekking Routes:
  • Easy Route: From Lohagadwadi village (4-5 km, 1-2 hours)
  • Moderate Route: From Bhaje Caves (6-7 km, 2-3 hours)

Things to Do:
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails and historic fortifications
  • Hiking: Climb to nearby viewpoints for breathtaking views
  • Photography: Capture stunning scenery and architecture
  • Camping: Overnight stays allowed with permission

Tips and Essentials:
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.)
  • Trekking Difficulty: Easy to moderate
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts in Lonavala

Safety Precautions:
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife

Nearby Attractions:
  • Bhaje Caves: Ancient Buddhist rock-cut caves
  • Visapur Fort: Nearby fort with stunning views
  • Lonavala Lake: Scenic lake with boating facilities
  • Khandala: Popular hill station with scenic views

How to Reach:
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Pune (60 km)
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Lonavala (10 km)
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai and Pune

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Karnala Fort

Karnala Fort is a historic fortification located in Raigad District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location
Karnala Fort, Karnala, Raigad District, Maharashtra, India
History
Built in the 13th century by the Yadava dynasty, Karnala Fort was later conquered by the Mughal Empire and the Marathas.
Places to Explore
  • Karnala Fort: Main fortification with impressive architecture.
  • Karnala Bird Sanctuary: Home to over 150 species of birds.
  • Thumbs Up Point: Scenic viewpoint.
  • Panorama Point: Offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape.
  • Ancient Temples: Dedicated to Lord Shiva and Goddess Bhagavati.

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the fort.
  • Birdwatching: Spot rare and exotic bird species.
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets.

Tips and Essentials
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February.
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.).
  • Trekking Difficulty: Easy to moderate.
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies.
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts.

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat.
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear.
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife.

Nearby Attractions
  • Alibaug Beach: Famous for water sports and scenic views.
  • Murud-Janjira Fort: Historic sea fort.
  • Raigad Fort: Former capital of the Maratha Empire.
  • Mhasla: Scenic village with ancient temples.

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm.
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm.

Entry Fees
  • Indians: ₹50.
  • Foreigners: ₹300.

How to Reach
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Mumbai (60 km).
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Panvel (40 km).
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities.

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Panhala Fort

Panhala Fort is a historic fortification located in Kolhapur, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location:
Panhala Fort, Kolhapur, Maharashtra, India
History:
Built in the 12th century by Raja Bhoja II of the Shilahara dynasty, Panhala Fort was strategically located to control the trade routes between Kolhapur and the coastal regions.
Places to Explore:
  • Panhala Fort: Main fortification with impressive architecture
  • Teen Darwaza: Historic entrance gate
  • Ambarkhana: Granary built by Shivaji Maharaj
  • Sajja Kothi: Historic palace
  • Mahakali Temple: Ancient temple dedicated to Goddess Mahakali

Things to Do:
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the fort
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets
  • Camping: Overnight stays allowed with permission

Tips and Essentials:
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.)
  • Trekking Difficulty: Easy to moderate
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts in Kolhapur

Safety Precautions:
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife

Nearby Attractions:
  • Kolhapur: Explore the city's historic architecture, temples, and markets
  • Mahalaxmi Temple: Famous temple dedicated to Goddess Mahalaxmi
  • Rankala Lake: Scenic lake with boating facilities
  • Jyotiba Temple: Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Jyotiba

How to Reach:
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Kolhapur (20 km)
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Kolhapur (18 km)
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Daulatabad Fort

Daulatabad Fort is a mediaeval fortress located in Aurangabad district, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

History
Built in the 12th century by the Yadava dynasty, Daulatabad Fort was later conquered by the Delhi Sultanate, followed by the Mughal Empire and the Marathas.
Places to Explore
  • Chand Minar: 64-metre-high tower commemorating the capture of the fort.
  • Chini Mahal: Beautiful palace built by the Mughal Empire.
  • Jama Masjid: Historic mosque built during the Delhi Sultanate period.
  • Bhadkal Gate: Main entrance gate to the fort.
  • Mahakali Temple: Ancient temple dedicated to Goddess Mahakali.

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the fort.
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets.
  • Guided Tours: Join a guided tour to explore the fort's hidden passages and secrets.

Tips and Essentials
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February.
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.).
  • Trekking Difficulty: Moderate.
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies.
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury hotels in Aurangabad.

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat.
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear.
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife.

Nearby Attractions
  • Aurangabad: Explore historic architecture, temples, and markets.
  • Ajanta and Ellora Caves: UNESCO World Heritage Sites famous for ancient Buddhist rock-cut caves.
  • Bibi Ka Maqbara: Beautiful mausoleum built by Azam Shah.
  • Panchakki: Historic water mill.

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm.
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm.

Entry Fees
  • Indians: ₹50
  • Foreigners: ₹300

How to Reach
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Aurangabad (22 km).
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Aurangabad (20 km).
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities.

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Vijaydurg Fort

Vijaydurg Fort is a 16th-century sea fort located in Sindhudurg District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

History
Built by Raja Bhoja II of the Shilahara dynasty in 1209, Vijaydurg Fort was later conquered by Shivaji Maharaj in 1653.
Places to Explore
  • Main Entrance: Impressive entrance gate.
  • Shivaji Maharaj's Palace: Ancient palace ruins.
  • Bhagavati Temple: 200-year-old temple dedicated to Goddess Bhagavati.
  • LightHouse: Offers stunning views of the Arabian Sea.
  • Shipyard: Remains of the historic shipyard.

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the fort.
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets.
  • Beach Activities: Enjoy nearby beaches like Vijaydurg Beach.

Tips and Essentials
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February.
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.).
  • Trekking Difficulty: Easy to moderate.
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies.
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts.

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat.
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear.
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife.

Nearby Attractions
  • Sindhudurg Fort: Another historic sea fort.
  • Tarkarli Beach: Famous for water sports and scenic views.
  • Malvan: Explore historic architecture and local cuisine.
  • Kunkeshwar Temple: Ancient Shiva temple.

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm.
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm.

Entry Fees
  • Indians: ₹50.
  • Foreigners: ₹300.

How to Reach
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Goa (140 km).
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Kudal (40 km).
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities.

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Malangad

Malanggad Fort is a 17th-century hill fort located in Raigad District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location
Malanggad Fort, Raigad District, Maharashtra, India
History
Built by the Siddi dynasty in 1662, Malanggad Fort was later conquered by the Marathas.
Places to Explore
  • Malanggad Fort: Main fortification with impressive architecture.
  • Temple of Lord Ganesh: Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Ganesh.
  • Water Tanks: Historic water storage systems.
  • Watchtowers: Offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape.
  • Caves: Explore nearby caves.

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the fort.
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets.
  • Hiking: Climb to nearby viewpoints.
  • Camping: Overnight stays allowed with permission.

Tips and Essentials
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February.
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.).
  • Trekking Difficulty: Moderate to challenging.
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies.
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts.

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat.
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear.
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife.

Nearby Attractions
  • Raigad Fort: Former capital of the Maratha Empire.
  • Murud-Janjira Fort: Historic sea fort.
  • Alibaug Beach: Scenic beach with stunning views.
  • Kihim Beach: Scenic beach with stunning views.

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm.
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm.

Entry Fees
  • Indians: ₹50.
  • Foreigners: ₹300.

How to Reach
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Mumbai (100 km).
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Panvel (50 km).
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities.

Visapur Fort

Visapur Fort is an 18th-century hill fort located in Pune District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location
Visapur Fort, Pune District, Maharashtra, India
History
Built by the Marathas in 1713, Visapur Fort played a significant role in the Maratha Empire's expansion.
Places to Explore

  • Old Military Stables: Historic stables for military horses.
  • Water Tanks: Ancient water storage systems.
  • Watchtowers: Offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape.
  • Caves: Explore nearby caves.

Rajgad Fort

Rajgad Fort is a 17th-century hill fort located in Pune District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location
Rajgad Fort, Pune District, Maharashtra, India
History
Built by Shivaji Maharaj in 1646, Rajgad Fort served as the capital of the Maratha Empire.
Places to Explore
  • Rajgad Fort: Main fortification with impressive architecture.
  • Sanjeevani Machi: Eastern wing of the fort with stunning views.
  • Suvela Machi: Western wing of the fort with ancient temples.
  • Padmavati Machi: Central wing of the fort with historic ruins.
  • Temple of Goddess Padmavati: Ancient temple dedicated to Goddess Padmavati.

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the fort.
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets.
  • Hiking: Climb to nearby viewpoints.
  • Camping: Overnight stays allowed with permission.

Tips and Essentials
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February.
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.).
  • Trekking Difficulty: Moderate to challenging.
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies.
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts.

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat.
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear.
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife.

Nearby Attractions
  • Torna Fort: Historic fortification.
  • Sinhagad Fort: Popular trekking destination.
  • Pune City: Explore historic landmarks and cultural attractions.
  • Raigad Fort: Former capital of the Maratha Empire.

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm.
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm.

  • Foreigners: ₹300.

Underi Fort

Underi Fort is a 17th-century sea fort located in Raigad District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location
Underi Fort, Raigad District, Maharashtra, India
History
Built by the Siddi dynasty in 1680, Underi Fort was later conquered by the Marathas.
Places to Explore
  • Underi Fort: Main fortification with impressive architecture.
  • Lighthouse: Offers stunning views of the Arabian Sea.
  • Bhagavati Temple: Ancient temple dedicated to Goddess Bhagavati.
  • Caves: Explore nearby sea caves.
  • Beach: Scenic beach with stunning views.

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the fort.
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets.
  • Snorkelling and Scuba Diving: Explore nearby coral reefs.
  • Beach Activities: Enjoy nearby beaches.

Tokana Fort

Tikona Fort is a historic fortification located in Lonavala, Pune District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Location
Tikona Fort, Lonavala, Pune District, Maharashtra, India
History
Built in the 17th century by the Marathas, Tikona Fort played a significant role in the Maratha Empire's expansion.
Places to Explore
  • Tikona Fort: Main fortification with impressive architecture.
  • Trimbakeshwar Mahadev Temple: Ancient Shiva temple.
  • Vittalgad Fort: Nearby fortification.
  • Pawna Lake: Scenic lake with boating facilities.
  • Tikona Peth: Base village with historic significance.

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the fort.
  • Historical Exploration: Discover the fort's rich history and architecture.
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets.
  • Camping: Overnight stays allowed with permission.

Tips and Essentials
  • Best Time to Visit: October to February.
  • Entry Fee: ₹50 (approx.).
  • Trekking Difficulty: Easy to moderate.
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies.
  • Accommodation: Options range from budget-friendly guesthouses to luxury resorts.

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or extreme heat.
  • Terrain: Steep cliffs and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear.
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife.

Nearby Attractions
  • Lonavala: Popular hill station with scenic views.
  • Bhaja Caves: Ancient Buddhist rock-cut caves.
  • Lohagad Fort: Historic fortification.
  • Visapur Fort: Nearby fortification.

  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm.
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm.

  • Indians: ₹50.
  • Foreigners: ₹300.

How to Reach

  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Lonavala (20 km).
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Raigad

The Raigad is considered to be the greatest architectural achievement in the whole range of Indo architecture. Its recognised architectonic beauty has a rhythmic combination of solids and voids, concave and convex and light shadow; such as arches and domes further increases the aesthetic aspect. Not a piece of architecture, as other buildings are, but the proud passions of an emperor’s luxurious wrought in living stones.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Janjira

The word Janjira is a corruption of the word "jazira", which means "island" in the Arabic language. Murud was once known in Marathi as Habsan ("of the Habshi", that is, the Abyssinians). The name of the fort is a concatenation of the Konkani and Marathi words, "murud" and "Janjiri". The word "morod" is peculiar to Konkani and is absent in Marathi. Murud-Janjira is the local name of a famous fort and tourist spot situated on an island just off the coastal town of Murud, in the Raigad district of Maharashtra, India.[Malik Ambar is credited with the construction of the Janjira Fort in the Murud Area of present-day Maharashtra India.[After its construction in 1567 AD, the fort was key to the Sidis withstanding various invasion attempts by the Marathas, Mughals, and Portuguese to capture Janjira.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Shivneri

Shivneri got its name as it was under the possession of the Yadavas of Devagiri. This fort was mainly used to guard the old trading route from Desh to the port city of Kalyan. The place passed on to the Bahmani Sultanate after the weakening of Delhi Sultanate during the 15th century and it then passed on to the Ahmadnagar Sultanate in the 16th century. In 1595, a Maratha chief named Maloji Bhosale, the grandfather of Shivaji Maharaj Bhosale, was ennobled by the Ahmadnagar Sultan, Bahadur Nizam Shah and he gave him Shivneri and Chakan. Shivaji Maharaj was born at the fort on 19 February 1630 (some accounts place it 1627), and spent his childhood there. Inside the fort is a small temple dedicated to goddess Shivai Devi,[2] after whom Shivaji was named. The English traveller Fraze visited the fort in 1673 and found it invincible. According to his accounts, the fort was well-stocked to feed thousand families for seven years. The fort came under the control of the British rule in 1819 after the Third Anglo-Maratha War.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Pratapgad

Pratapgad is a mountain fort located in Satara district, in the Western Indian state of Maharashtra. The fort is situated 24 kilometres from the Mahabaleshwar hill station. The fort is now a popular tourist destination. The fort's historical significance is due to the Battle of Pratapgad, which took place here on 10 November 1659, between Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and Bijapur Sultanate general Afzal Khan.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Purandar

The oldest known reference of existence of the Purandar fort dates back to the Yadava dynasty in the 11th century.[citation needed] After the defeat of the Yadavas by the foreign invaders,[citation needed] the territory surrounding the fort fell into the hands of the invaders who further fortified the Purandar Fort in 1350 A.D. During the early rule of the Bijapur and Ahmednagar kings, The Purandar Fort was among the forts directly under the Government rule and was never entrusted to Jagirdars.[4] Under the rule of the Berar Sultanate, the fort was besieged several times. To prevent the Purandar Fort from ever falling again, a sacrificial ritual was performed where a man and a woman were buried alive under one of the fort bastions to appease its patron deity.[5] Another ritual was soon performed where the king ordered a minister to bury a first-born son and his mother into the foundation of the bastion which was promptly done with a further offering of gold and bricks. When the bastion was finished, The minister, Yesaji Naik, was given possession of the Purandar Fort and the father of the sacrificed boy was rewarded with two villages.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Lohagad

The initial construction of Lohagad Fort is attributed to the Lohtamia dynasty, who ruled the region during the 10th century CE, the fort was under them for the longest period. [1] Lohagad has a long history with several dynasties occupying it at different periods of time: Lohtamia, Chalukyas, Rashtrakutas, Yadavas, Bahamanis, Nizams, Mughals and Marathas. Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj captured it in 1648 AD, but he was forced to surrender it to the Mughals in 1665 AD by the Treaty of Purandar. Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj recaptured the fort in 1670 AD and used it for keeping his treasury. This fort was used to keep the winnings from Surat. Later in Peshwa time Nana Phadnavis used this fort for living for some time and built several structures in the fort such as a big tank and a step-well.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Panhala

In 1659, after the death of the Bijapur general Afzal Khan, in the ensuing confusion Shivaji took Panhala from Bijapur.[5] In May 1660, to win back the fort from Shivaji, Adil Shah II (1656–1672) of Bijapur sent his army under the command of Siddi Johar to lay siege to Panhala. Shivaji fought back and they could not take the fort. The siege continued for 5 months, at the end of which all provisions in the fort were exhausted and Shivaji was on the verge of being captured.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Vijaydurg

In 1653, Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj captured this fort from Adil Shah of Bijapur and renamed it as "Vijay Durg". The original name of the fort was "Gheria" and the first fortification appears to have been constructed in 1200 during the regime of Raja Bhoj II. Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj developed Vijaydurg as an important base for Maratha warships.[4] Maratha Empire looked to be in a decline after the death of chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj in 1680, when his son and successor Sambhaji was captured by Mughal Emperor Aurangzeb and brutally tortured to death on 21 March 1689. Later in that year, the fort of Raigad fell in the hand of Mughals. Wife of Shambhaji Maharaj and his infant son Shahu Maharaj along with many others were captured and were treated as state prisoners.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Karnala

The fort was likely constructed before 1400, under Devagiri Yadavs(1248–1318) and the Tughlaq rulers (1318–1347), Karnala was the capital of the north Konkan districts of their respective empires.[2] It later fell under the command of the Gujarat Sultanate but in 1540 was taken over by Nizam Shah of Ahmednagar. The Gujarat sultans then requested the help of the Dom Francisco de Menenzes the commanding officer of the Portuguese at Bassien (modern day Vasai) to win it back. He ordered 500 of his soldiers to Karnala fort and they were able to capture it. The fort was left in charge of the Gujarat Sultanate but with Portuguese garrisons.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Suvarnadurg

The literal meaning of Suvanadurga in the Marathi language is "Golden Fort" as it was considered as the pride or the "feather in the golden cap of Marathas". Built by Adilshah Navy for defence purposes, the fort also had a shipbuilding facility. The basic objective of establishing the fort was to counter enemy attacks, mainly by the colonialists of Europe and also by the local chieftains.[4] In the past, the land fort and the sea fort were connected by a tunnel, but this is now defunct. The present approach to the sea fort is only by boats from the Harnai port on the headland. It is a protected monument.[5] The fort also includes another small land fort called the Kanakadurga at the base of headland of Harnai port on the coast. Building of the fort is credited to Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, founder of the Maratha Empire, in 1660. Subsequently, Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, other Peshwas and the Angres further fortified the forts for defence purposes.[

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Daulatabad

The area of the city the hill-fortress of Devagiri (sometimes Latinised to Deogiri). It stands on a conical hill, about 200 meters high. Much of the lower slopes of the hill has been cut away by Yadava dynasty rulers to leave 50-meter vertical sides to improve defenses. The fort is a place of extraordinary strength. The only means of access to the summit is by a narrow bridge, with the passage for not more than two people abreast, and a long gallery, excavated in the rock, which has, for the most part, a very gradual upward slope.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Shri Malangad

Malanggad is built on three levels. The lowest level is a plateau which is 1000 feet broad and 2500 feet long on which stands the Dargah of a Sufi saint - Haji Malang.[3] At the other end of the plateau is the Panchi Pir which lies almost at the edge of the rock and is named after the five pirs who accompanied Shree Malang Gad.[1] This plateau is called Pir Machi.[4] The next higher level is called the Sone Machi as it is the lower part of the fort. This is a projection of rock that is 70 feet broad and 100 feet long. It is shaped like an elephant trunk.[1] Malang Gad is different from other forts in Maharashtra. Whereas other forts have several gates and multiple watchtowers, the art of the main gate itself. With a wall with no machicolations to fire at the enemy and no fortifications, Malang Gad is one of the few forts to depend completely on natural aspects of the hill to defend itself.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Visapur

It was built during 1713-1720 CE by Balaji Vishwanath, the first Peshwa of Maratha Empire.[1][2] Visapur fort was built much later than Lohagad but the histories of the two forts are closely linked. Sunlit view of Visapur Fort In 1818, when reducing the Peshwa's forts, the strength of Lohagad and its fame as the treasury of the Maratha kingdom, caused the English to make special preparations for its attack. A detachment of 380 European and 800 native soldiers, with a battering train, summoned from Konkan, were joined by artillery from Chakan, and two other British battalions. On 4 March 1818, Visapur was attacked and occupied.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Tung

Tung Fort was built before 1600 CE. It was built by the Adil Shahi dynasty but was captured by Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.[3] It is a small fort, and able to hold not more than 200 troops at a time. As such, it would not have been able to defend itself on its own for a long time. Its shape and structure suggest that its main function was as a watchtower overlooking Maval region of the Pawana and Mulshi valleys guarding the road to Pune city. The Dhamale family, one of the Deshmukh from the Maval region, was charged with ensuring the security of Tung Fort. During invasion, it served to provide a temporary distraction for invaders. Thus, the major forts of Visapur and Lohagad would have time to prepare themselves to meet the invading army.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Tikona

Little is known about the origins of this fort. There is a vihara on the fort datable to circa seventh-eight centuries A.D.[2] Malik Ahmad Nizam Shah I of the Nizam Shahi dynasty conquered the fort in 1585 and annexed it to the Nizam territory. In 1657, Shivaji I brought the whole of Konkan, which had been Nizam territory, under his control when he conquered Tikona along with the forts of Karnala, Lohgad, Mahuli, Songad, Tala, and Visapur.[3] This fort was a strategic nexus: the centre of control for the entire Pawana Mawal region. In 1660, Dhamale family, the Deshmukhs from Maval region were charged with ensuring the security of fort Tikona. It was under the Dhamale Deshmukh family for a long time. Jaysingh invaded the region in 1665 and attacked the local villages but the forts held out. Tikona fort was surrendered to the Mughal warrior Kubadkhan, who had attacked the region together with Halal Khan and others, according to the Treaty of Purandar signed on 12 June 1665. Kubad Khan took over the fort on 18 June but it was later recaptured by the Marathas.[4] In 1682 King Sambhaji met Aurangzeb's son Akbar. After the meeting the Akbar was offered to stay on Tikona fort, however, he was shifted to Jaitapur as the climate didn't suit him. A small battle was fought by the Maratha army with the British in 1818 before it was captured by the latter.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Underi

Pratapgad is a mountain fort located in Satara district, in the Western Indian state of Maharashtra. The fort is situated 24 kilometres from the Mahabaleshwar hill station. The fort is now a popular tourist destination. The fort's historical significance is due to the Battle of Pratapgad, which took place here on 10 November 1659, between Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and Bijapur Sultanate general Afzal Khan.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Rajgad

The Rajgad Fort is located around 60 km (37 mi) to the south-west of Pune and about 15 km (9.3 mi) west of Nasrapur in the Sahyadris range. The fort lies 1,376 m (4,514 ft) above the sea level. The diameter of the base of the fort was about 40 km (25 mi) which made it difficult to lay siege on it, which added to its strategic value. The fort's ruins consist of palaces, water cisterns, and caves. This fort was built on a hill called Murumbadevi Dongar (mountain of the goddess Murumba). Rajgad boasts of the highest number of days stayed by Chhatrapati Shivaji on any fort.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Sinhagad

Shahaji Bhosale, as the commander of Ibrahim Adil Shah II, was entrusted with the control of the Pune region. His son Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, refused to accept the Adilshahi and initiated the task of setting up Swarajya. Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj gained control of Kondana in 1647 by convincing Siddi Amber, the Adilshahi Sardar who controlled the fort, that he, the son of Shahaji Bhosale, could manage the fort's defences optimally. Bapuji Mudgal Deshpande played a key role in this activity. Adil Shah jailed Siddi Amber for this treasonous act and schemed to get it back. He imprisoned Shahaji Bhosale for a concocted crime and informed Shivaji. In 1649, Adil Shah traded the fort for Shahaji's release. Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj recaptured it in 1656 again with the help of Bapuji Mudgal Deshpande who convinced the Fort commander by giving land in the newly created Khed Shivapur village and peacefully gained control of the fort. This fort saw attacks by Mughals in 1662, 1663, and 1665. In 1664, Shaista Khan, a Mughal general, tried to bribe the people of the fort to hand it over to him but was unsuccessful.Through the Treaty of Purandar in 1665, that Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj entered into with Mughal general Mirza Raja Jai Singh I the fort passed into the Mughal hands.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Torna

This fort is believed to have been constructed by the Shiva Panth in the 13th century. A Menghai Devi temple, also referred to as the Tornaji temple, is situated near the entrance of the fort. Malik Ahmed, a Bahamani ruler, captured this fort during the reign of Alauddin Khilji during the late 1470s. In 1646, Shivaji captured this fort at the age of sixteen [citation needed], thus making it one of the first forts that would become one of the forts of the Maratha empire. Shivaji renamed the fort ' 'Prachandagad' ' as Torna, and constructed several monuments and towers within it. In the 18th century, the Mughal empire briefly gained control of this fort after the assassination of Shivaji's son Sambhaji raje. Aurangzeb, the then Mughal emperor, renamed this fort Futulgaib in recognition of the difficult defense the Mughals had to overcome to capture this fort. It was restored to the Maratha confederacy by the Treaty of Purandar.

Page no: 4/4

Video Explaination:

Harishchandragad

Its origin is said to have been in the 6th century, during the rule of Kalachuri dynasty. The citadel was built during this era. The various caves probably have been carved out in the 11th century. In these caves are idols of Lord Vishnu. Though the cliffs are named Taramati and Rohidas, they are not related to Ayodhya. Great sage Changdev (one who created the epic Tatvasaar), used to meditate here in the 14th century. The caves are from the same period. The various constructions on the fort and those existing the surrounding region point to the existence of diverse cultures here. The carvings on the temples of Nageshwar (in Khireshwar village), in the Harishchandreshwar temple and in the cave of Kedareshwar indicate that the fort belongs to the medieval period, since it is related to mahadeva as a totem of tribes Mahadev Koli. They were controlling the fort before Moguls. Later the fort was under the control of Moguls. The Marathas captured it in 1747.

Maharastra Forts:

Raigad Fort

Raigad Fort was the capital of the Maratha Empire from 1674 to 1818. It is located on a hilltop in the Sahyadri Mountains and is considered to be one of the most important forts in Indian history. The fort is well-preserved and offers stunning views of the surrounding countryside.

Shivneri Fort

Shivneri Fort is an ancient military fortification located near Junnar in Pune district in Maharashtra, India. It is the birthplace of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, the founder of the Maratha Empire. The fort is situated on a hilltop that overlooks the Junnar city. It is a triangular-shaped fort with seven well-defended gates.

Sinhagad Fort

Sinhagad, ealier known as ‘Kondhana’ is the most prominent and popular fort in Pune.It is located at village Donaje, taluka-Haveli. It is 25 km away from Pune on a hill 1290 m high. Tanaji Malusare-Chh. Shivaji’s trsusted and brave general,fought a battle here all alone with the Mughal army.

Torna Fort

Torna Fort, also known as Prachandagad, is a large fort located in Pune district, in the Indian state of Maharashtra. It is historically significant because it was the first fort captured by Shivaji I in 1646, at the age of 16.

Harishchandragad Fort

Harishchandra Fort is a hill fort in the Ahilyanagar(Ahmednagar) district of India. Its history is linked with that of Malshej Ghat, Kothale village and it has played a role in guarding and controlling the surrounding region.

Pratapgad Fort

Pratapgad Fort is a mountain fort located in Satara district, in the Western Indian state of Maharashtra. The fort is situated 24 kilometres (15 min) from the Mahabaleshwar hill station. The fort is now a popular tourist destination.

Janjira Fort

Murud-Janjira is the local name of a famous fort and tourist spot situated on an island just off the coastal town of Murud, in the Raigad district of Maharashtra, India.Malik Ambar is credited with the construction of the Janjira Fort in the Murud Area of present-day Maharashtra India. After its construction in 1567 AD, the fort was key to the Sidis withstanding various invasion attempts by the Marathas, Mughals, and Portuguese to capture Janjira.

Purandar

Purandar Fort is a mountain fort in Pune district in Western Indian state of Maharashtra, India. The fort stands at 1,374 metres (4,508 ft) above the sea level in the Western Ghats, 50 kilometres (31 mi) to the southeast of Pune.[1] The twin forts of Purandar and Vajragad (or Rudramal) of which the latter is the smaller of the two, is located on the eastern side of the main fort rising 1,347 metres (4,419 ft) above sea level.[1] The village of Purandar takes its name from this fort.

Lohagad

Lohagad is one of the many hill forts of Maharashtra state in India. Situated close to the hill station Lonavala and 52 km (32 mi) northwest of Pune, Lohagad rises to an elevation of 1,033 m (3,389 ft) above sea level. The fort is connected to the neighboring Visapur fort by a small range. The fort was under the Lohtamia empire for the majority of the time, with a short period of 5 years under the Mughal empire.

Panhala Fort

Panhala fort, is located in Panhala, 20 kilometres northwest of Kolhapur in Maharashtra, India. It is strategically located looking over a pass in the Sahyadri mountain range which was a major trade route from Bijapur in the interior of Maharashtra to the coastal areas.Due to its strategic location, it was the centre of several skirmishes in the Deccan involving the Marathas, the Mughals and the British the grand son's of chhatrapati shivaji maharaj East India Company, the most notable being the Battle of Pavan Khind.

Daulatabad Fort

Daulatabad Fort originally Deogiri Fort, is a historic fortified citadel located in Daulatabad village near Aurangabad, Maharashtra, India. It was the capital of the Yadavas (9th century – 14th century CE), for a brief time the capital of the Delhi Sultanate (1327–1334), and later a secondary capital of the Ahmadnagar Sultanate (1499–1636).

Vijaydurg Fort

Vijaydurg, the oldest fort on the Sindhudurg coast, was constructed during the regime of Raja Bhoja II of the Shilahar dynasty and restructured by Shivaji. Earlier, the fort encompassed an area of 5 acres and was surrounded by sea on all four sides. Over the years the eastern trench was reclaimed and a road constructed thereon. Presently the area of fort is about 17 acres and is surrounded by the Arabian Sea on three sides.

Karnala Fort

Karnala Fort (also called Funnel Hill[1]) is a hill fort in Raigad district, Maharashtra, India, about 10 km from Panvel city. Currently it is a protected place lying within the Karnala Bird Sanctuary. It was a place of strategic importance since it overlooked the Bor pass, which connected the Konkan coast to the interior of Maharashtra (Deccan Plateau)[1] on the main trade route between these areas.

Suvarnadurg Fort

The literal meaning of Suvanadurga in the Marathi language is "Golden Fort" as it was considered as the pride or the "feather in the golden cap of Marathas". Built by Adilshah Navy for defence purposes, the fort also had a shipbuilding facility. The basic objective of establishing the fort was to counter enemy attacks, mainly by the colonialists of Europe and also by the local chieftains.

Shri Malangad Fort

Murud-Janjira is the local name of a famous fort and tourist spot situated on an island just off the coastal town of Murud, in the Raigad district of Maharashtra, India.Malik Ambar is credited with the construction of the Janjira Fort in the Murud Area of present-day Maharashtra India. After its construction in 1567 AD, the fort was key to the Sidis withstanding various invasion attempts by the Marathas, Mughals, and Portuguese to capture Janjira.

Visapur Fort

It was built during 1713-1720 CE by Balaji Vishwanath, the first Peshwa of Maratha Empire. Visapur fort was built much later than Lohagad but the histories of the two forts are closely linked. Sunlit view of Visapur Fort In 1818, when reducing the Peshwa's forts, the strength of Lohagad and its fame as the treasury of the Maratha kingdom, caused the English to make special preparations for its attack.

Tung Fort

Tung Fort was built before 1600 CE. It was built by the Adil Shahi dynasty but was captured by Chatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. It is a small fort, and able to hold not more than 200 troops at a time. As such, it would not have been able to defend itself on its own for a long time.

Tikona Fort

Tikona also known as Vitandgad, is the dominant hill fort in Maval in western India. It is located near Kamshet around 60 km from Pune. The village nearest to the fort is called Tikona-Peth. The 3500 foot high hill is pyramidal in shape and the name Tikona means "triangular".

Underi Fort

The fort is a trekking destination noted for the large doors, the temple of 'Trimbakeshwar Mahadev', seven water tanks (seven water tanks), and some Satvahan caves. Trek organisers also commend the views of Pavana dam and the nearby forts of Tung, Lohagad and Visapur.There is a good view of Pavana lake from the summit.

Rajgad Fort

Rajgad (literal meaning ruling fort) is a Hill region fort situated in the Pune district of Maharashtra, India. Formerly known as Murumbdev, the fort was the first capital of the Maratha Empire under the rule of Chhatrapati Shivaji for almost 26 years, after which the capital was moved to the Raigad Fort.[1] Treasures discovered from an adjacent fort called Torna were used to completely build and fortify the Rajgad Fort

Page no: 2/4

WaterFalls:

Malshej Falls

A waterfall is any point in a river or stream where water flows over a vertical drop or a series of steep drops. Waterfalls also occur where meltwater drops over the edge of a tabular iceberg or ice shelf. Waterfalls can be formed in several ways, but the most common method of formation is that a river courses over a top layer of resistant bedrock before falling onto softer rock, which erodes faster, leading to an increasingly high fall. Waterfalls have been studied for their impact on species living in and around them.

Randha Falls

Humans have had a distinct relationship with waterfalls since prehistory, travelling to see them, exploring and naming them. They can present formidable barriers to navigation along rivers. Waterfalls are religious sites in many cultures. Since the 18th century, they have received increased attention as tourist destinations, sources of hydropower, and—particularly since the mid-20th century—as subjects of research.

Umbrella Falls

Waterfalls can occur along the edge of a glacial trough, where a stream or river flowing into a glacier continues to flow into a valley after the glacier has receded or melted. The large waterfalls in Yosemite Valley are examples of this phenomenon, which is referred to as a hanging valley. Another reason hanging valleys may form is where two rivers join and one is flowing faster than the other.

Bhivpuri Falls

Waterfalls are an important factor in determining the distribution of lotic organisms such as fish and aquatic invertebrates, as they may restrict dispersal along streams. The presence or absence of certain species can have cascading ecological effects, and thus cause differences in trophic regimes above and below waterfalls. Certain aquatic plants and insects also specialize in the environment of the waterfall itself.

Tamhini Falls

Waterfalls also affect terrestrial species. They create a small microclimate in their immediate vicinity characterized by cooler temperatures and higher humidity than the surrounding region, which may support diverse communities of mosses and liverworts. Species of these plants may have disjunct populations at waterfall zones far from their core range.

Devkund Falls

Waterfalls provide nesting cover for several species of bird, such as the black swift and white-throated dipper. These species preferentially nest in the space behind the falling water, which is thought to be a strategy to avoid predation.

Dudhsagar Falls

Waterfalls provide nesting cover for several species of bird, such as the black swift and white-throated dipper. These species preferentially nest in the space behind the falling water, which is thought to be a strategy to avoid predation.

Ellora caves Falls

Waterfall sites more than any other geomorphic feature attract and hold the interest of the general public. Because they have such a popular approval waterfalls are not given serious attention by some students of systematic geomorphology. This attitude is not to be commended. Waterfalls are significant items for geomorphic investigation.

Kalu Falls

Many explorers have visited waterfalls. European explorers recorded waterfalls they came across. In 1493, Christopher Columbus noted Carbet Falls in Guadeloupe, which was likely the first waterfall Europeans recorded seeing in the Americas. In the late 1600s, Louis Hennepin visited North America, providing early descriptions of Niagara Falls and the Saint Anthony Falls. The geographer Brian J. Hudson argues that it was uncommon to specifically name waterfalls until the 1700s.

Amboli Falls

Waterfalls are often visited by people simply to see them. Hudson theorizes that they make good tourism sites because they are generally considered beautiful and are relatively uncommon.[40] Activities at waterfalls can include bathing, swimming, photography, rafting, canyoning, abseiling, rock climbing, and ice climbing.[35] Waterfalls can also be sites for generating hydroelectric power and can hold good fishing opportunities.

Vihigaon Falls

Waterfalls at least as early as in Ancient Rome and China. However, many waterfalls were essentially inaccessible due to the treacherous terrain surrounding them until improvements began to be made such as paths to the falls, becoming common across the United Kingdom and America in the 1800s and continuing through the 1900s and into the 21st century. Remote waterfalls are now often visited by air travel.

Dhobi Falls

Human development has also threatened many waterfalls. For instance, the Guaíra Falls, once one of the most powerful waterfalls in the world, were submerged in 1982 by a human-made dam, as were the Ripon Falls in 1952. Conversely, other waterfalls have seen significantly lower water levels as a result of diversion for hydroelectricity, such as the Tyssestrengene in Norway.

Vajrai Falls

Waterfalls play a role in many cultures, as religious sites and subjects of art and music. Many artists have painted waterfalls and they are referenced in many songs.

Thoseghar Falls

There are thousands of waterfalls in the world, though no exact number has been calculated. The World Waterfall Database lists 7,827 as of 2013, but this is likely incomplete; as noted by Hudson, over 90% of their listings are in North America. Many guidebooks to local waterfalls have been published.

Kune Falls

A waterfall is generally defined as a point in a river where water flows over a steep drop that is close to or directly vertical. In 2000 Mabin specified that "The horizontal distance between the positions of the lip and plunge pool should be no more than c 25% of the waterfall height." There are various types and methods to classify waterfalls.[1] Some scholars have included rapids as a subsection.[2] What actually constitutes a waterfall continues to be debated.

Lingmala falls

Waterfalls are sometimes interchangeably referred to as "cascades" and "cataracts", though some sources specify a cataract as being a larger and more powerful waterfall and a cascade as being smaller.[6] A plunge pool is a type of stream pool formed at the bottom of a waterfall.[7] A waterfall may also be referred to as a "foss" or "force

Marleshwar Falls

A river sometimes flows over a large step in the rocks that may have been formed by a fault line. Waterfalls can occur along the edge of a glacial trough, where a stream or river flowing into a glacier continues to flow into a valley after the glacier has receded or melted.

Dugarwadi Falls

There are thousands of waterfalls in the world, though no exact number has been calculated. The World Waterfall Database lists 7,827 as of 2013, but this is likely incomplete; as noted by Hudson, over 90% of their listings are in North America.

Barki Falls

There are thousands of waterfalls in the world, though no exact number has been calculated. The World Waterfall Database lists 7,827 as of 2013, but this is likely incomplete; as noted by Hudson, over 90% of their listings are in North America.

Page no: 3/4

Detailed View :

Malshej Falls

Malshej Falls is a scenic waterfall located in the Western Ghats, Pune District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Overview
  • 650 feet high waterfall
  • Surrounded by lush greenery and scenic views
  • Part of the Malshej Ghat region

Location
  • District: Pune
  • State: Maharashtra
  • Nearest City: Pune (120 km)
  • Nearest Town: Malshej (10 km)

Places to Explore
  • Malshej Falls: Main attraction
  • Malshej Ghat: Scenic drive and hiking trails
  • Ajoba Hill Fort: Historic fort (20 km)
  • Harishchandragad Fort: Historic fort (30 km)
  • Shivneri Fort: Birthplace of Shivaji Maharaj (40 km)

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Hike to the waterfall and surrounding hills
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and scenery
  • Picnic: Enjoy a relaxing day out with family and friends
  • Swimming: Take a dip in the natural pool (with caution)
  • Birdwatching: Spot various bird species in the region

Tips and Essentials
  • Wear comfortable footwear and clothing
  • Carry sunscreen, hats, and water
  • Respect local environment and wildlife
  • Follow safety guidelines and instructions
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or flooding
  • Terrain: Slippery rocks and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm

Entry Fees
Free entry, but may vary for surrounding attractions
Accommodation
  • Budget-friendly guesthouses
  • Luxury resorts
  • Camping options available

Additional Tips:
  • Carry a first-aid kit
  • Respect local customs and traditions
  • Follow local guidelines for photography
  • Enjoy the scenic views and peaceful atmosphere!

Best Time to Visit Malshej Falls:
  • Monsoon season (June to September) for maximum water flow
  • Winter season (October to February) for pleasant weather

Nearby Attractions:
  • Malshej Ghat
  • Ajoba Hill Fort
  • Harishchandragad Fort
  • Shivneri Fort
  • Bhimashankar Temple (60 km)

How to Reach
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Kalyan (80 km)
  • By Bus: State transport buses available from Pune and nearby cities
  • By Car: Drive from Pune (120 km) or Mumbai (150 km)

Page no: 3/4

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Randha Falls

Randha Falls is a scenic waterfall located in Ahmednagar District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Overview
  • Height: 170 feet
  • Type: Seasonal waterfall
  • Best Time to Visit: July to October (monsoon season)

Location
  • District: Ahmednagar
  • State: Maharashtra
  • Nearest City: Akole (40 km)

Places to Explore
  • Randha Falls: Main waterfall with stunning views
  • Akole Town: Nearby town with historic landmarks
  • Sangamner Town: Nearby town with cultural attractions (60 km)
  • Bhandardara Dam: Nearby dam with scenic views (80 km)

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the waterfall
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and moments
  • Swimming: Enjoy swimming in designated areas
  • Picnic: Relax and enjoy a picnic with family and friends
  • Birdwatching: Spot rare bird species in the surrounding forests

Tips and Essentials
  • Wear comfortable footwear and clothing
  • Carry sunscreen, hats, and water
  • Respect local culture and environment
  • Follow safety guidelines and instructions
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or flooding
  • Terrain: Slippery rocks and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm

Entry Fees
  • Indians: ₹50
  • Foreigners: ₹300

Accommodation
  • Budget-friendly guesthouses
  • Luxury resorts
  • Camping options available

Additional Tips:
  • Carry a first-aid kit
  • Respect local customs and traditions
  • Follow local guidelines for photography
  • Enjoy the scenic views and serenity of the waterfall!

Best Time to Visit Randha Falls:
  • Monsoon season (July to October) for maximum water flow
  • Post-monsoon season (November to December) for lush green surroundings
  • Winter season (January to February) for pleasant weather

Nearby Attractions:
  • Bhandardara Dam
  • Sangamner Town
  • Akole Town
  • Shirdi Sai Baba Temple (120 km)

Randha Falls Trek:
  • Distance: 2 km
  • Duration: 1-2 hours
  • Difficulty Level: Easy to moderate
  • Trail Type: Scenic trails through forests and hills

How to Reach
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Pune (160 km)
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Sangamner (60 km)
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities

Umbrella Falls

Umbrella Falls is a scenic waterfall located in Bhandardara, Ahmednagar District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Overview
  • Height: 500 feet
  • Type: Seasonal waterfall
  • Best Time to Visit: July to October (monsoon season)

  • Randha Falls: Nearby waterfall (20 km)

How to Reach

  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities

Bhivpuri Falls

Tamhini Falls

Devkund Falls

Devkund Waterfall is a scenic waterfall located in Raigad District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Overview
  • Height: 50-70 feet
  • Type: Seasonal waterfall
  • Best Time to Visit: July to October (monsoon season)

Location
  • District: Raigad
  • State: Maharashtra
  • Nearest City: Mumbai (120 km)
  • Nearest Town: Bhira (20 km)

Places to Explore
  • Devkund Waterfall: Main waterfall with stunning views
  • Bhira Dam: Nearby dam with scenic views
  • Andharban Forest: Scenic forest with trekking trails
  • Tamhini Ghat: Scenic hill station with breathtaking views

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the waterfall
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and moments
  • Swimming: Enjoy swimming in designated areas
  • Picnic: Relax and enjoy a picnic with family and friends
  • Birdwatching: Spot rare bird species in the surrounding forests

Tips and Essentials

  • Carry sunscreen, hats, and water
  • Respect local culture and environment
  • Follow safety guidelines and instructions
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies

  • Terrain: Slippery rocks and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife

How to Reach
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Mumbai (120 km)
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Bhira (20 km)
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm

Entry Fees
  • Indians: ₹50
  • Foreigners: ₹300

Accommodation
  • Budget-friendly guesthouses
  • Luxury resorts
  • Camping options available

Additional Tips:
  • Carry a first-aid kit
  • Respect local customs and traditions
  • Follow local guidelines for photography
  • Enjoy the scenic views and serenity of the waterfall!

Best Time to Visit Devkund Waterfall:
  • Monsoon season (July to October) for maximum water flow
  • Post-monsoon season (November to December) for lush green surroundings
  • Winter season (January to February) for pleasant weather

Nearby Attractions:
  • Bhira Dam
  • Andharban Forest
  • Tamhini Ghat
  • Raigad Fort

Page no: 3/4

Detailed View :

Previous Next

Ellora Caves Falls

Ellora Caves Waterfall is a scenic waterfall located near the Ellora Caves, a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Aurangabad District, Maharashtra, India. Here's essential information for tourists:

Overview
  • Height: 30-40 feet
  • Type: Seasonal waterfall
  • Best Time to Visit: July to October (monsoon season)

Location
  • District: Aurangabad
  • State: Maharashtra
  • Nearest City: Aurangabad (30 km)
  • Nearest Town: Ellora (5 km)

Places to Explore
  • Ellora Caves Waterfall: Main waterfall with stunning views
  • Ellora Caves: UNESCO World Heritage Site with ancient rock-cut temples
  • Grishneshwar Jyotirlinga Temple: Ancient Shiva temple
  • Daulatabad Fort: Historic fort with scenic views

Things to Do
  • Trekking: Explore scenic trails surrounding the waterfall
  • Photography: Capture stunning views and moments
  • Sightseeing: Explore Ellora Caves and nearby historical sites
  • Picnic: Relax and enjoy a picnic with family and friends
  • Birdwatching: Spot rare bird species in the surrounding forests

Tips and Essentials
  • Wear comfortable footwear and clothing
  • Carry sunscreen, hats, and water
  • Respect local culture and environment
  • Follow safety guidelines and instructions
  • Food and Water: Carry sufficient supplies

Safety Precautions
  • Weather: Avoid visiting during heavy rainfall or flooding
  • Terrain: Slippery rocks and uneven terrain, wear proper footwear
  • Wildlife: Be aware of snakes and other wildlife

How to Reach
  • By Air: Nearest airport is Aurangabad (30 km)
  • By Train: Nearest railway station is Aurangabad (30 km)
  • By Road: State transport buses and private vehicles available from Mumbai, Pune, and nearby cities

Timings
  • Summer: 9 am to 6 pm
  • Winter: 9 am to 5 pm

Entry Fees
  • Indians: ₹50
  • Foreigners: ₹300

Accommodation
  • Budget-friendly guesthouses
  • Luxury resorts
  • Camping options available

Additional Tips:
  • Carry a first-aid kit
  • Respect local customs and traditions
  • Follow local guidelines for photography
  • Enjoy the scenic views and serenity of the waterfall!

Best Time to Visit Ellora Caves Waterfall:
  • Monsoon season (July to October) for maximum water flow
  • Post-monsoon season (November to December) for lush green surroundings
  • Winter season (January to February) for pleasant weather

Nearby Attractions:
  • Ellora Caves
  • Grishneshwar Jyotirlinga Temple
  • Daulatabad Fort
  • Ajanta Caves (100 km)
