    Pench National Park

    Location
    Seoni and Chhindwara Districts, Madhya Pradesh, India

    Overview
    Pench National Park protects diverse flora and fauna, including endangered species, in a stunning landscape.
    Key Attractions
    • Tiger Reserve: Home to majestic Bengal tigers.
    • Wildlife: Leopards, sloth bears, deer, and various bird species.
    • Forests: Tropical deciduous and evergreen forests.
    • River Pench: Scenic views and riverine habitat.

    Tourist Information
    • Timing: 6:00 AM - 6:00 PM
    • Entry Fee: ₹150 (Indians), ₹600 (Foreigners)
    • Best Time to Visit: October to June
    • Area: 758 sq km
    • Elevation: 500-600 meters above sea level
    • Note: Pench National Park remains closed from July 1 to September 30 for monsoon season.

    How to Reach
    • By Road: From Nagpur: 90 km (2 hours)
    • By Train: Nagpur Railway Station (90 km) or Seoni Railway Station (30 km)
    • By Air: Nagpur Airport (90 km)

    Public Transportation
    • State Transport buses from Nagpur, Jabalpur, and Mumbai
    • Private bus operators

    Activities
    • Wildlife Safari: Guided tours.
    • Trekking: Explore surrounding forests.
    • Birdwatching: Spot rare species.

    Tips
    • Wear comfortable clothing and shoes.
    • Bring water, snacks, and sun protection.
    • Respect wildlife habitats.

    Nearby Attractions
    • Pench Dam (10 km)
    • Seoni City (30 km)
    • Chhindwara City (60 km)
    • Kanha National Park (200 km)

    Accommodation
    • Forest Rest Houses
    • Private resorts and hotels

    Conservation Efforts
    • Tiger conservation program
    • Habitat restoration
    • Anti-poaching initiatives

    Awards and Recognition
    • Winner of the "Best Management Award" in 2011
    • Featured in BBC's "Tiger: Spy in the Jungle" documentary

    Time to Visit for Wildlife Spotted
    • Tigers: November to May
    • Leopards: December to April
    • Sloth bears: March to June

    Detailed View :

    Previous Next

    Kanha wildlife Sanctuary

    Location
    Mandla and Balaghat District, Madhya Pradesh, India

    Overview
    Kanha National Park, also known as Kanha Tiger Reserve, is one of India's premier tiger reserves, protecting diverse flora and fauna.
    Key Attractions
    • Tiger Reserve: Home to majestic Bengal tigers.
    • Wildlife: Leopards, sloth bears, deer, and various bird species.
    • Forests: Tropical deciduous and evergreen forests.
    • Bamboo Forests: Dense bamboo thickets.

    Tourist Information
    • Timing: 6:00 AM - 6:00 PM
    • Entry Fee: ₹150 (Indians), ₹600 (Foreigners)
    • Best Time to Visit: October to June
    • Area: 940 sq km
    • Elevation: 600-900 meters above sea level
    • Note: Kanha National Park remain closed from July 1 to September 30 for monsoon season.

    How to Reach
    • By Road: From Jabalpur: 160 km (3.5 hours) or From Nagpur: 260 km (5 hours)
    • By Train: Jabalpur Railway Station (160 km) or Gondia Railway Station (200 km)
    • By Air: Jabalpur Airport (160 km) or Nagpur Airport (260 km)

    Public Transportation
    • State Transport buses from Jabalpur, Nagpur, and Mumbai
    • Private bus operators

    Activities
    • Wildlife Safari: Guided tours.
    • Trekking: Explore surrounding forests.
    • Birdwatching: Spot rare species.

    Tips
    • Wear comfortable clothing and shoes.
    • Bring water, snacks, and sun protection.
    • Respect wildlife habitats.

    Nearby Attractions
    • Bamni Dadar (10 km)
    • Kanha Museum (5 km)
    • Mandla City (30 km)
    • Bandhavgarh National Park (200 km)

    Accommodation
    • Forest Rest Houses
    • Private resorts and hotels

    Conservation Efforts
    • Tiger conservation program
    • Habitat restoration
    • Anti-poaching initiatives

    Awards and Recognition
    • Winner of the "Best Management Award" in 2010
    • Featured in BBC's "Tiger: Spy in the Jungle" documentary

    Best Time to Visit for Wildlife Spotted
    • Tigers: November to May
    • Leopards: December to April
    • Sloth bears: March to June

    Kanha National Park is divided into four zones:
    • Kanha Zone
    • Kisli Zone
    • Mukki Zone
    • Sarhi Zone

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Gorewada National Park

    Balasaheb Thackeray Gorewada International Zoological Park, known earlier as the Gorewada Zoo,is a zoo in the Nagpur district of the Indian state of Maharashtra. Upon completion, this is likely to be one of the largest captive zoo safaris in India, covering over 1914 hectares of land adjoining Gorewada Lake.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Tadoba National Park

    The Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve is a wildlife sanctuary in Chandrapur district of Maharashtra state in India. It is Maharashtra's oldest and largest national park. Created in 1955, the reserve includes the Tadoba National Park and the Andhari Wildlife Sanctuary. The reserve consists of 577.96 square kilometres (223.15 sq mi) of reserved forest and 32.51 square kilometres (12.55 sq mi) of protected forest.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Melghat National Park

    Melghat tiger reserve is located in the Amaravati district of Maharashtra. Melghat Tiger Reserve is located on the southern offshoot of the Satpura Hill Range in Central India, called Gavilgarh Hill. It is 225 km west of Nagpur. It was established as a wildlife sanctuary in 1967, and was declared a tiger reserve in 1974. It was among the first nine tiger reserves notified in 1973-74 under Project Tiger, a wildlife conservation project initiated in India in 1972 to protect Bengal tigers. It was the first tiger reserve of Maharashtra.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Sanjay Gandhi Natioanl Park

    Sanjay Gandhi National Park is an 87 km2 (34 sq mi) protected area in Mumbai, Maharashtra. It was established in 1969 with its headquarters situated at Borivali. The 2400-year-old Kanheri caves, sculpted by monks out of the rocky basaltic cliffs, lie within the park. The rich flora and fauna of the Sanjay Gandhi National Park attract more than 2 million visitors every year.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Nawegaon National Park

    Navegaon National Park is a National park located in the Arjuni Morgaon subdivision of Gondia district in state of Maharashtra, India. The Dr Salim Ali Bird Sanctuary, Navegaon is home to almost 60% of the bird species found in entire Maharashtra. Every winter, flocks of migratory birds visit the lake. The national park has diverse type of vegetation ranging from dry mixed forest to moist forest. The forest type is 5 A/C3. Southern tropical dry deciduous forest.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Amte National Park

    Amte's Animal Ark houses about 115 orphaned animals. Madia-Gond tribes weren't an agrarian community and would hunt for animals. It was to conserve animals that Lok Biradari Prakalp opened a rescue centre. The tribe still hunts for animals during the festivals and give young orphaned animals to the Ark. In exchange, they get rice, vegetables or clothing. The Ark also conducts "Save the snakes" campaign. Dr. Prakash Amte believes that everyone should be sensitive and loving towards all animals. That's why, the care animals receive in the Ark is unlike other zoos.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Rajiv Gandhi National Park

    The Rajiv Gandhi Zoological Park, commonly known as the Rajiv Gandhi Zoo or Katraj Zoo, is located in Katraj, Pune district, Maharashtra State, India. It is managed by the Pune Municipal Corporation. The 130-acre (53 ha) zoo is divided into three parts: an animal orphanage, a snake park and a zoo and includes the 42-acre (17 ha) Katraj Lake.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Veer Jijamata Bhosale Botanical Zoo

    Jijamata Udyaan, also known as the Byculla Zoo and formerly Victoria Gardens, is a zoo and garden covering 50 acres located at Byculla, in the heart of Mumbai, India. It is the oldest public garden in Mumbai.After Indian independence, it was named after Jijamata, the mother of Shivaji, the first Maratha emperor.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Chandoli National Park

    Chandoli National Park is a national park established in Sangli district in May 2004.Earlier it was a Wildlife Sanctuary declared in 1985. Chandoli Park is notable as the southern portion of the Sahyadri Tiger Reserve, with Koyna Wildlife Sanctuary forming the northern part of the reserve.

    Page no: 4/4

    Video Explaination:

    Gugamal National Park

    Gugamal National Park is an Indian national park that is one of seven protected areas in the Melghat Tiger Reserve.Founded on 22 February 1974, this park is located in the Chikhaldara and Dharni tehsils of Amravati, Maharashtra.

    Video Explaination:

    Phansad Wildlife Sanctuary

    Phansad Wildlife Sanctuary, spread over 69.79 sq km in Raigad, Maharashtra, is home to diverse flora and fauna. The sanctuary protects rare species like Indian giant squirrels, bonnet macaques, and 200+ bird species. Trekking, birdwatching, and nature photography are popular activities amidst its lush forests and scenic hills. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Malvan Marine Sanctuary

    Malvan Marine Sanctuary, spanning 29.03 sq km in Sindhudurg, Maharashtra, protects coral reefs, mangroves, and marine life. Home to dolphins, sea turtles, and 101 fish species. Activities include snorkeling, scuba diving, and boat tours. Famous for its clear waters, coral gardens, and historic Sindhudurg Fort nearby. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Karnala Bird Sanctuary

    Karnala Bird Sanctuary, nestled in Raigad, Maharashtra, is a 4.45-square-kilometer haven for avian enthusiasts, boasting an impressive 222 bird species. This sanctuary is a paradise for birdwatching, trekking, and nature photography. Rare and exotic species such as the Malabar trogon and Oriental dwarf kingfisher can be spotted amidst the thicket vegetation and deciduous forests. Adventure seekers can trek to the historic Karnala Fort, while families can enjoy picnic spots amidst serene surroundings. With its unique blend of natural beauty and biodiversity, Karnala Bird Sanctuary is an ideal getaway for nature lovers and wildlife enthusiasts. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Sagareshwar Deer Sanctuary

    Sagareshwar Deer Sanctuary, located in Kolhapur, Maharashtra, spans 10.87 square kilometers and serves as a vital habitat for endangered Indian deer species. Established in 1985, this sanctuary provides a protected environment for spotted deer, sambhar deer, and barking deer, along with other wildlife such as wild boars, langurs, and peacocks. With over 200 bird species, lush forests, waterfalls, and trekking trails, Sagareshwar offers an immersive experience for nature enthusiasts. Visitors can engage in wildlife watching, birdwatching, trekking, and nature photography amidst the deciduous forests and thicket vegetation. Conservation efforts focus on protecting the deer species and preserving their habitat through research and education programs. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Bhimashankar Wildlife Sanctuary

    Bhimashankar Wildlife Sanctuary, spread over 130.78 sq km in Pune and Raigad, Maharashtra, protects rare flora and fauna. Home to the endangered giant squirrel, Indian bison, and 115 bird species. Features lush forests, waterfalls, and trekking trails. Sacred Bhimashankar Shiva Temple is nestled within the sanctuary. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Rehkuri Blackbuck Sanctuary

    Rehkuri Blackbuck Sanctuary, located in Ahmednagar, Maharashtra, spans 2.17 sq km. A protected habitat for endangered blackbucks, this sanctuary features grasslands and scrub forests. Other residents include wolves, hyenas, and 115 bird species. Ideal for wildlife watching, photography, and birding. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Dajipur Wildlife Sanctuary

    Dajipur Wildlife Sanctuary, spread over 51.78 sq km in Kolhapur, Maharashtra, protects endangered wildlife. Home to Indian bison (gaur), elephants, sloth bears, and 145 bird species. Features deciduous forests, grasslands, and Radhanagari Dam. Ideal for trekking, wildlife watching, and birding. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Nagzira Wildlife Sanctuary

    Nagzira Wildlife Sanctuary, covering 161.33 sq km in Gondia and Bhandara districts, Maharashtra, conserves biodiversity. Home to tigers, leopards, sloth bears, and 150 bird species. Features forests, hills, and waterfalls. Activities include wildlife watching, trekking, and birding. A proposed tiger reserve, promoting ecosystem balance and conservation. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Nagzira Wildlife Sanctuary

    Nagzira Wildlife Sanctuary, covering 161.33 sq km in Gondia and Bhandara districts, Maharashtra, conserves biodiversity. Home to tigers, leopards, sloth bears, and 150 bird species. Features forests, hills, and waterfalls. Activities include wildlife watching, trekking, and birding. A proposed tiger reserve, promoting ecosystem balance and conservation. Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Pench National Park

    Pench National Park, spanning 758 sq km in Madhya Pradesh and Maharashtra, is a tiger reserve. Home to majestic tigers, leopards, sloth bears, and 220 bird species. Features teak forests, hills, and Pench River. Activities include wildlife safaris, trekking, and birding. Inspiration for Rudyard Kipling's "The Jungle Book." Click on this for more Information.

    Video Explaination:

    Kanha National Park

    Kanha National Park and Wildlife Sanctuary, Madhya Pradesh's largest tiger reserve, spans 940 sq km. Home to Bengal tigers, leopards, sloth bears, and 300 bird species. Features lush sal forests, grasslands, and Banjar River. Inspired Rudyard Kipling's "The Jungle Book." Ideal for wildlife safaris, trekking, and birding. Click on this for more Information.

    Page no: 2/4

    Places of Worship:

    Siddhivinayak Temple

    The Shri Siddhivinayak Ganapati Mandir is a Hindu temple dedicated to Ganesha. It is located in Prabhadevi neighbourhood of Mumbai, Maharashtra, India.It was originally built by Laxman Vithu and Deubai Patil on 19 November 1801. It is one of the most popular Hindu temples in Mumbai.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Shirdi Sai Baba Temple

    Shirdi is a popular religious tourist spot with hordes of visitors thronging this place in huge numbers every day. Shirdi is the abode of the great saint “Sai Baba”. The main attraction of Shirdi is the Sai Baba Samadhi Mandir, situated in the heart of the town of Shirdi. Sai Baba’s body has been laid to eternal rest here.
    Click on this for more Information

    Shri Gajanan Maharaj Temple,Shegaon

    The Gajanan Maharaj Temples are built to honor Sant Gajanan Maharaj, an Indian holy saint widely popular in Maharashtra, India and also well known in rest of the world. Maharaj lived during the late 19th century and early 20th century, spending most of his life in Shegaon, where he achieved Samadhi on September 8, 1910.
    Click on this for more Information

    Ganpatipule Temple

    Ganpatipuleis a coastal town in Ratnagiri district of Maharashtra. Due to its Ganpati mandir the town is popular Hindu pilgrimage and tourists destination.The town is situated near Ratnagiri city which is seat of its namesake district, Chiplun town is located its north side.
    Click on this for more Information

    Mahalakshmi Temple,Mumbai

    Mahalaxmi Temple is a Hindu temple, dedicated to Mahalakshmi the central deity of Devi Mahatmyam, located in Mumbai, India. It is one of the most famous temples of the city of Mumbai. The temple was built in 1831 by Dhakji Dadaji (1760–1846), a Hindu merchant.
    Click On this for more Information

    Jejuri Khandoba Temple

    The Khandoba Temple of Jejuri is a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Khandoba, located on a hill in the town of Jejuri, Maharashtra, India.It is one of the most prominent Hindu pilgrimage centres of Maharashtra.
    Click on this for more Information

    Vitthal temple [Pandharpur]

    The Vithoba Temple, officially known as Shri Vitthal-Rukmini Mandir, is a Hindu temple in Pandharpur, in the Indian state of Maharashtra.It is the main centre of worship for Vithoba, a form of the god Vishnu or Krishna, and his consort Rakhumai. It is Classified one among the 108 Abhimana Kshethram of Vaishnavate tradition.
    Click on this for more Information

    Trimbakeshwar Temple

    Trimbakeshwar Shiva Temple is an ancient Hindu temple in the town of Trimbak, in the Trimbakeshwar tehsil in the Nashik District of Maharashtra, India, 28 km from the city of Nashik and 40 km from Nashik road.It is dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva and is one of the twelve jyotirlingas.
    Click on this for more Information

    Bharadi Devi Temple, Malvan

    Anganewadi in Malvan is more famous for its Bharadi Devi temple and the most popular fair called Anganewadi Jatra which is held annually. The most interesting thing about this fair is its changing date which is finalized by mutual consent in February every year. There are many legends about the appearance of the deity in this village of Malvan District.
    Click on this for more Information

    Isckon Temple,Mumbai

    ISCKON Temple is a divine and spiritual getaway from all the hustle and bustle of the capital city of Mumbai. Dedicated to Lord Krishna who is considered as the eighth avatar of Lord Vishnu, the temple is clad in marble and glass. Meters away from the Juhu Beach.
    Click on this for more Information

    Mumba Devi Temple

    Mumba Devi Mandir is an temple in Mumbai, Maharashtra, India dedicated to the goddess Mumbā, the local incarnation of the Devi (Mother Goddess). Mumba Devi is the goddess of the city of Mumbai. The name Mumbai is derived from Mumba Devi.

    Jivdani Temple

    The temple is on the hill, almost 1500 ft from the sea-level. (More reliable sources cite 728 ft) The Goddess rests in a temple situated about 1465 steps above the ground on a hill that forms a part of the Satpura Range in Virar, a northern Mumbai suburb, about 60 km away from Mumbai. The hill offers a very picturesque view of Virar and its vicinity. During the nine days of the Navratri festival many followers visit the shrine.

    Grishneshwar temple

    Grushneshwar Jyotirlinga is a Hindu temple of Shiva in Verul village of Aurangabad district, Maharashtra, India. It is one of the 12 Jyotirlinga mandirs.The mandir is a national protected site, one and a half kilometers away from the Ellora Caves, 30 kilometres (19 miles) north-west of the city Aurangabad, and 300 kilometres (190 miles) east-northeast far from Mumbai.Grushneshwar is mentioned in Shiva Purana, Skanda Purana, the Ramayana and the Mahabharata.

    Ozar Temple

    Grushneshwar Jyotirlinga is a Hindu temple of Shiva in Verul village of Aurangabad district, Maharashtra, India. It is one of the 12 Jyotirlinga mandirs.The mandir is a national protected site, one and a half kilometers away from the Ellora Caves, 30 kilometres (19 miles) north-west of the city Aurangabad, and 300 kilometres (190 miles) east-northeast far from Mumbai.Grushneshwar is mentioned in Shiva Purana, Skanda Purana, the Ramayana and the Mahabharata.

    Shree Vighnahar Ganpati Temple

    The Vigneshwara Temple or Vighnahar Ganapati Temple of Ozar (also spelt as Ojhar or Ojzar) is a Hindu temple dedicated to Ganesha, the elephant-headed god of wisdom. The temple is one of the Ashtavinayaka, the eight revered shrines of Ganesha in Maharashtra, India.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Harishchandreshwar Temple

    Harishchandreshwar Temple is located in Harishchandragad Fort, a hill fort in the Ahmednagar district of Maharashtra, India. This mesmerizing temple is nestled in the greenery of the fort carved out of a single huge black rock.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Tulja Bhawani Temple

    Shree Tulaja Bhavani Temple is a Hindu temple dedicated to goddess Bhavani. It is located in Tuljapur in Dharashiv district of Maharashtra, India, and is considered as one of the 51 Shakti Pithas. It is situated 45 km from Solapur. The temple was built in 12th century CE by Maratha Mahamandaleshwara Māradadeva of the Kadamb dynasty
    Click on this for more Information.

    Dagdusheth Ganpati temple

    The Dagadusheth Halwai Ganapati temple is a Hindu Temple located in Pune and is dedicated to the Hindu god Ganesh. The temple is visited by over one hundred thousand pilgrims every year. Devotees of the temple include celebrities and chief ministers of Maharashtra who visit during the annual ten-day Ganeshotsav festival
    Click on this for more Information.

    Kunkeshwar Temple

    Kunkeshwar is a village in Maharashtra, India situated on the bank of Arabian Sea. There is a temple for the Hindu deity Shiva in the village.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Jyotiba Temple

    Jyotiba Temple is a holy site of Hinduism near Wadi Ratnagiri in Kolhapur district of Maharashtra state in western India. The deity of the temple is known by the same name. An annual fair takes place on the full moon night of the Hindu months of Chaitra and Vaishakha.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Saptashrungi Mata Temple

    Saptashrungi or Saptashringi is a site of Hindu pilgrimage situated 60 kilometres (37 mi) from Nashik in Indian state of Maharashtra. According to Hindu traditions, the goddess Saptashrungi Nivasini dwells within the seven mountain peaks.It is located in Nanduri, Kalwan taluka, a small village near Nashik in India.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Mahalaxmi Temple

    Mahalaxmi Temple is one of the most famous temples of Mumbai situated on Bhulabhai Desai Road in Mahalaxmi area. It is dedicated to Mahalakshmi the central deity of Devi Mahatmyam. The temple was built in 1831 by Dhakji Dadaji, a Hindu merchant. The Mahalaxmi temple contains images of the Tridevi goddesses Mahakali, Mahalakshmi.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Hiranyakeshi Temple

    Sacred to goddess Parvati, Hiranyakeshi Temple is the point from where Hiranyakeshi river originates. In the main sanctum of the temple, there is an idol of Devi Hiranyakeshi (a form of Goddess Parvati) with golden hair and self-manifested red color Shivling called as Hiranyakeshwar.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Marleshwar Temple

    Marleshwar is a small Shiva temple in Sangameshwar subdivision of Ratnagiri district in the Indian state of Maharashtra. It takes about one and a half hours to reach by road; visitors then climb 300–400 steps, which are lined with refreshment stalls to keep the climbing pilgrims refreshed.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Kailasa Temple

    The Kailasha or Kailashanatha temple is the largest of the rock-cut temples at the Ellora Caves near Aurangabad district, Maharashtra of Maharashtra, India.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Renuka Mata, Mahurgad

    Mahur or Mahurgad is a town and religious place in Nanded district of Maharashtra, India. Mahur is the birthplace of Hindu God Dattatreya.Dattatreya parents Atri Rishi and Sati Anasuya Mata lived here. Brahmadev, Vishnudev and Lord Shiva once got a news about Anusaya Mata that there is no one more pious and pure as her.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Puj Chaliha Sahib Jhulelal Mandir

    Puj Chaliha Chaliha Sahib Jhulelal Mandir is located in Ulhasnagar 5. This was built during the independence / partition of India in year 1947. This temple is famous all across the world for Jhulelal Sain, Akhand Jyot and Jhulelal Amrit Sarovar.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Bhau Parsram Jhulelal Mandir

    After 1947 partition of India, Sindhis left their homeland Sindh, leaving behind their Sindhi Culture, Worship Places and Mandirs of their deity Sai Jhulelal. Entire Hindu Sindhi community got scattered all over the world. For unifying Sindhis and reviving their culture, there was a strong need for Sindhi Schools.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Gurudwara Guru Nanak Darbar

    The Guru Nanak Darbar Gurdwara is a Sikh Gurdwara situated in the town of Gravesend, Kent. It is the largest Gurdwara in Europe and also one of the largest outside India
    Click on this for more Information.

    Jhulelal Mandir Bhawan

    Located at a distance of 2 km from the Nanded bus stand. Jhulelal Mandir Bhavan offers four bedded AC and non-AC rooms. Parking space for vehicles is available. The stay provides amenities like hot water, clean drinking water, LCD TV and extra mattresses at affordable prices. Check-in and check-out times are at 9:00 AM.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Gurudwara Khalsa Sabha

    Gurudwara Khalsa Sabha also known as Khalsa Sabha, Matunga is a Gurudwara in Matunga Road, Mumbai. It is adjacent Guru Nanak High School, Mahim sharing common compound. It is located behind the City Light Cinema, Guru Nanak Marg, in Matunga Road
    Click on this for more Information.

    Gurudwara Shri Guru Singh Sabha

    Gurdwara Sri Guru Singh Sabha is a Sikh gurdwara, or Sikh house of worship, in Delhi, India. It also known as the Gurdwara Pahari Wala or Pahariwala.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Gurudwara Shri Nanak Jhira

    Guru Nanak Jhira Sahib is a Sikh historical shrine situated in Bidar, Karnataka. Gurdwara Nanak Jhira Sahib was built in 1948 and is dedicated to the first Sikh guru, Guru Nanak. Bidar has a very long association with Sikhism as this is the home town of Bhai Sahib Singh, one of the Panj Pyare (five beloved ones), who offered to sacrifice their heads.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Gurudwara Shri Hargobindpur

    GURDWARA SRI GURU HARGOBIND SAHIB is situated in Village Jhootha Jartarpur, Teh Baba Bakala, Distt Amritsar. SRI GURU HARGOBIND SAHIB JI came here from Sri Hargobindpur Sahib via Ghuman and further went to Butala and Baba Bakala.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Redi Ganpati

    The Ganapati temple of Redi is located approximately 30 km from Vengurla, in the small village of Redi, Maharashtra, India. The town in which this temple is situated contains iron ore mines and the Ganpati (Ganesha) idol was found in one of the mines near Rewati port in 1976.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Vajreshwari Temple

    The Shree Vajreshwari Yogini Devi Mandir is a Hindu temple dedicated to the goddess Vajreshwari, located in the town Vajreshwari, 75 km away from Mumbai. The town, earlier known as Vadvali, was renamed Vajreshwari in honour of the presiding deity of the temple.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Swaminarayan temple

    Shri Swaminarayan Mandir, Mumbai is a Hindu temple and a part of the Swaminarayan Sampraday. This Swaminarayan Temple is located in the Bhuleshwar area of Mumbai and is the oldest Swaminarayan Mandir in Mumbai, being over a hundred years old.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Shri Swami Samarth Mandir, Akkalkot

    Shri Swami Samarth Maharaj also known as Swami of Akkalkot was an Indian Hindu god of the Dattatreya Tradition. He lived during the nineteenth century from 1858 to 1878 and is a known spiritual figure in various Indian states including Karnataka and Maharashtra.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Shani Shingnapur Temple

    Shani Shingnapur or Shani Shinganapur or Shingnapur is a village in the Indian state of Maharashtra. Situated in Nevasa Taluka in Ahmednagar district, the village is known for its popular temple of Shani, the Hindu god associated with the planet Saturn. The village is 35 kilometres from the city of Ahmednagar.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Ekvira Devi Mandir, Karla

    The Ekvira Aai Mandir is a Hindu temple located near the Karla Caves near Lonavala in Maharashtra, India. Here, the worship of the goddess Ekvira is carried on right next to the caves, once a center of Buddhism. The temple is a prime spot of worship for the Aagri and Koli people.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Wai Ghat and Temples

    Wai has the epithetic name "Dakshin Kashi" (Kashi or Varanasi of the South) because of the city's more than 100 temples. Wai is known in Maharashtra for its ghats on the banks of the Krishna River and its temples, especially the Dholya ganapati temple on Ganapati Ghat.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Gagangiri Maharaj Temple, Khopoli

    Swami Gagangiri Maharaj was an Indian Hindu saint and Guru of the Nath Sampradaya. He is one of the most influential Hathayogis of modern India. Gagangiri Maharaj was particularly known for his water penance and intense meditation practices. He is considered the incarnation of Adi Dattatreya himself.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Mount Mary Basilica

    For over a hundred years situated atop a hillock near Lands End Bandra, overlooking the Arabian Sea is Mount Mary's Basilica a beautiful edifice in stone that simply stands out in its grandeur, an abode of tranquility, peace, reassurance and hope!
    Click on this for more Information.

    St. Xavier's Church

    St. Francis Xavier's Church, Giriz is a Catholic church in the village of Giriz in the coastal town of Vasai in the city of Vasai-Virar in Maharashtra State, India. It serve as the parish church for Giriz, within the Diocese of Vasai.
    Click on this for more Information.

    St Patrick's Cathedral

    St. Patrick's Cathedral is a Catholic cathedral in the Midtown Manhattan neighborhood of New York City. It is the seat of the Archbishop of New York as well as a parish church.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Ambroli Church

    Ambroli Church is a Church of North India church in Girgaum, Mumbai that was established in 1831 by the Scottish missionary John Wilson.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Christ Church

    Christ Church in Byculla, Mumbai, is affiliated to the Church of North India and was built in 1833 as an Anglican church. The church's establishment has been the subject of a myth that it was built to suit the convenience of the Governor of Bombay.
    Click on this for more Information.

    All Saints Church

    All Saints' Church on Little Gibbs Road in Malabar Hill, Mumbai, India is affiliated to the Church of North India. It was built in 1881 as an Anglican church for the local congregation that had to earlier travel some 8 kilometres to St. Thomas Cathedral in Fort.
    Click on this for more Information.

    The Roman Catholic Church

    The Catholic Church, also known as the Roman Catholic Church, is the largest Christian church, with 1.28 to 1.39 billion baptized Catholics worldwide as of 2024
    Click on this for more Information.

    St. Anne's Church

    Construction of the Church of St. Anne began in 1577 by Monsignor Francisco de Rego (1681–1689). It was completed in 1695, by his successor, Rev. Fr. Antonio Francisco da Cunha.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Jama Masjid

    The Jama Mosque is a quadrangular structure of brick and stone, encircled by a ring of terrace roofed and double storeyed buildings, the ground floors of which are let out as shops. The chief or eastern gate of the mosque leads directly across an open courtyard to the ancient tank, which is now furnished with masonry steps and embankments.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Haji Ali Masjid

    Later, Pir Haji Ali Shah Bukhari had a recurring and disturbing dream that he had injured Earth by his act. Full of remorse and grief from that day he started keeping unwell. Then with the permission of his mother, he traveled to India with his brother and finally reached the shore of Mumbai – near Worli or at some place opposite the present tomb.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Masjid-e-umer

    The current structure was built in its current shape by the Ayyubid Sultan Al-Afdal ibn Salah ad-Din in 1193 to commemorate the prayer of the caliph Omar.[3] The entrance to the Church of the Holy Sepulchre had by then moved from the east to the south of the church, as a result of repeated destructive events that affected the Holy Sepulchre.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Alamgir Mosque

    The mosque is architecturally a blend of Islamic and Hindu architecture. The mosque has high domes and minarets. Two of its minarets were damaged; one minaret collapsed killing a few people and the other was officially brought down owing to stability concerns.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Damdi Masjid

    The mosque facade has three pointed arches, which lead into the prayer hall. Square pylons are provided at all four corners of the building, upon which rise slender minarets.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Kali Masjid

    The Kali Masjid is located inside a rectangular walled compound, closed on three sides with an arcade in the front. The entrance is through a large stone gate, flanked by stone jali screens, painted white. The prayer hall is topped by corner finials with fluted domical tops. Octagonal columns carry six small domes within. The mosque's principal dome.
    Click on this for more Information.

    Page no: 3/4

    Detailed View :

    Previous Next

    Siddhivinayak Temple

    Overview
    Siddhivinayak Temple is a renowned Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha, located in Prabhadevi, Mumbai, Maharashtra.

    History
    Built in 1801 by Laxman Vithu and Deubai Patil, the temple was initially a small structure. In 1952, it was rebuilt and expanded.
    Architecture
    The temple features a beautiful mix of Indian architecture, with a striking cream-colored exterior and intricate carvings. The sanctum sanctorum houses a majestic black stone idol of Lord Ganesha.
    Attractions
    • The iconic Ganesha idol
    • Beautiful carvings and sculptures
    • Inner sanctum with golden ceiling
    • Wooden doors with intricate carvings
    • Tuesday evening aartis (prayers)
    Tourist Information
    • Location: SK Bole Marg, Prabhadevi, Mumbai
    • Timings: 5:30 AM - 10:00 PM
    • Best Time to Visit: Early morning or evening
    • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
    • Tuesday evening aartis (prayers)
    • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
    Tips and Precautions
    • Be prepared for crowds and long queues
    • Remove shoes before entering the temple
    • Follow temple rules and traditions
    • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
    • Avoid carrying valuables
    • Stay hydrated
    Nearby Attractions
    • Haji Ali Dargah (3.5 km)
    • Mahalakshmi Temple (4.5 km)
    • Gateway of India (5.5 km)
    • Marine Drive (6 km)
    • Juhu Beach (10 km)
      • How to Reach
      • By Air: Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport (15 km)
      • By Rail: Dadar Railway Station (3 km)
      • By Road: Bus and taxi services available
      Food
      Try local street food, like vada pav and pani puri, or visit nearby restaurants serving Maharashtrian cuisine.
      Festivals and Events
      • Ganesh Chaturthi (August-September)
      • Vinayaka Chaturthi (September)
      • Tuesdays (special aartis and darshan)

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View:

      Previous Next

      Shirdi Sai Baba Temple

      Overview
      Shirdi Sai Baba Temple is a revered spiritual destination dedicated to Shirdi Sai Baba, a 19th-century saint and fakir.

      History
      Shirdi Sai Baba lived in Shirdi from 1858 to 1918. After his samadhi (passing away), his devotees built the temple in 1922.
      Location
      Shirdi, Ahmednagar District, Maharashtra, India.
      Temple Complex
      • Samadhi Mandir (main temple)
      • Dwarkamai (Sai Baba's mosque)
      • Gurusthan (Sai Baba's guru's shrine)
      • Chavadi (Sai Baba's occasional residence)
      • Museum
      Nearby Attractions
      Shani Shingnapur (35 km).
      Attractions
      • Sai Baba's Samadhi (burial site)
      • Beautiful marble idol of Sai Baba
      • Museum's artifacts and exhibits
      Tourist Information
      • Timings: 4:00 AM - 10:00 PM
      • Best Time to Visit: Early morning or evening
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Be prepared for crowds and long queues
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Follow temple rules and traditions
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Shirdi Airport (15 km)
      • By Rail: Sainagar Shirdi Railway Station (1 km)
      • By Road: Bus and taxi services from major cities

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Shri Gajanan Maharaj Temple

      Overview
      Shri Gajanan Maharaj Temple is a revered spiritual destination in Shegaon, Maharashtra, dedicated to Gajanan Maharaj, a 19th-century saint.

      Location
      Shegaon, Buldhana District, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      • 5:00 AM - 9:30 PM
      • Abhishek: 7:30 AM - 10:00 AM
      • Mahaprasad: 10:00 AM - 1:00 PM
      Foods
      Try local Maharashtrian cuisine, like vada pav, misal pav, and puran poli and specially the Shegaon Kachoris
      Attractions
      • Gajanan Maharaj's Samadhi (burial site)
      • Beautiful idol of Gajanan Maharaj
      • Free Mahaprasad (unlimited meals) for devotees
      Tourist Information
      • Timings: 4:00 AM - 10:00 PM
      • Best Time to Visit: September to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Be prepared for crowds and long queues
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Follow temple rules and traditions
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Aurangabad Airport (200 km)
      • By Rail: Shegaon Railway Station (walking distance) or Free Bus Facilities
      • By Road: Bus and taxi services from major cities

      Ganpati Pule Temple

      Overview
      Ganpatipule Temple is a renowned Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha, located on the Konkan coast in Ratnagiri district, Maharashtra.

      Location
      Ganpatipule, Ratnagiri District, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      • 5:00 AM - 9:00 PM
      • Darshan: 6:00 AM - 12:00 PM, 4:00 PM - 8:00 PM
      Foods
      Try local Konkani cuisine, like fish curry, rice, and kokam sharbat.
      Attractions
      • Self-manifested (Swayambhu) Ganesha idol
      • Nearby Jaigad Fort and Light House
      • Scenic views of the Arabian Sea
      Tourist Information
      • Timings: 4:00 AM - 10:00 PM
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Follow temple rules and traditions
      How to Reach

      • By Rail: Ratnagiri Railway Station (45 km)
      • By Road: Bus and taxi services from major cities

      • 5:00 AM - 9:00 PM

      Try local Mumbai street food, like vada pav, pani puri, and bhelpuri.
      Attractions
      • Beautiful idol of Goddess Mahalakshmi
      • Stunning architecture with intricate carvings
      • Vibrant festival celebrations

      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple

      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Follow temple rules and traditions

      Vitthal Temple,Pandharpur

      Overview
      Vitthal Temple, also known as Vitthala-Rukmini Temple, is a sacred Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Vitthal (Lord Krishna) and Goddess Rukmini, located in Pandharpur, Solapur District, Maharashtra.

      Location
      Pandharpur, Solapur District, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      • 5:00 AM - 10:00 PM
      • Darshan: 6:00 AM - 12:00 PM, 4:00 PM - 8:00 PM
      Attractions
      • Beautiful idols of Lord Vitthal and Goddess Rukmini
      • Sculptures of other Hindu deities
      • Scenic views of the Bhima River
      Tourist Information
      • Timings: 4:00 AM - 10:00 PM
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Follow temple rules and traditions
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Solapur Airport (70 km)
      • By Rail: Pandharpur Railway Station (walking distance)
      • By Road: Bus and taxi services from major cities
      Festivals and Events
      • Ashadhi Ekadashi (June-July)
      • Vitthal-Rukmini Wedding Ceremony (February-March)
      • Navratri (September-October)
      • Kartiki Ekadashi (October-November)

      Trimbakeshwar Temple

      Overview
      Trimbakeshwar Temple is a revered Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shiva, located in Trimbakeshwar, Nashik District, Maharashtra. It is one of the 12 Jyotirlinga temples in India.

      Location
      Trimbakeshwar, Nashik District, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      • 6:00 AM - 9:00 PM
      • Darshan: 7:00 AM - 12:00 PM, 4:00 PM - 7:00 PM
      Attractions
      • Sacred Jyotirlinga (Shiva Linga)
      • Beautiful temple architecture
      • Kusavarta Kund (holy pond)
      Tourist Information
      • Timings: 4:00 AM - 10:00 PM
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Take a dip in the Kusavarta Kund.
      • Try local street food and handicrafts.
      • Explore nearby attractions like Nashik City.
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Nashik Airport (35 km)
      • By Rail: Nashik Road Railway Station (30 km)
      • By Road: Bus and taxi services from major cities
      Festivals and Events
      • Mahashivratri (February-March)
      • Navratri (September-October)
      • Diwali (October-November)
      • Trimbakeshwar Festival (July-August)

      Mumba Devi Temple

      Overview
      Mumba Devi Temple is a revered Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Mumba, the patron deity of Mumbai.

      Location
      Bhuleshwar, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      • Morning: 6:00 AM - 12:00 PM
      • Afternoon: 1:00 PM - 7:00 PM
      History
      • Built in 1675 by the Gujarati community
      • Rebuilt in 1737 and 1965
      • Ancient temple with rich cultural significance
      Attractions
      • Colorful architecture with intricate carvings
      • Beautiful frescoes depicting mythological scenes
      • Sacred shrine with a golden kalash (dome)
      • Vibrant marketplace surrounding the temple
      Tourist Information
      • Timings: 4:00 AM - 10:00 PM
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals and Events
      • Navratri: 9-day festival with Garba and Dandiya Raas
      • Dussehra: Victory of good over evil
      • Makar Sankranti: Harvest festivals
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (BOM) - 15 km
      • By Train: Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus (CSMT) - 3 km
      • By Bus: Regular buses from CSMT and other parts of Mumbai

      Page no: 3/4

      • Renovated in the 19th century

      Grishneshwar temple

      Overview
      Grishneshwar Temple, located in Verul, Maharashtra, is one of the 12 Jyotirlinga temples in India, dedicated to Lord Shiva. Here's essential information:

      Location
      Aurangabad district, Maharashtra, India.
      Temple Timming
      • Timing: 5:00 AM - 9:00 PM.
      History
      • Built in the 16th century by Maloji Bhosale, Shahaji Bhosale's father.
      • Rebuilt in the 18th century by Ahilyabai Holkar.
      • Considered one of the holiest Shiva temples.
      Attractions
      • Main shrine of Lord Grishneshwar (Shiva).
      • Beautiful Nandi Mandap.
      • Sculptures of various Hindu deities.
      • Sacred kund (water tank).
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      How to Reach
      • Nearest airport: Aurangabad Airport (IXU) (35 km away).
      • Nearest railway station: Aurangabad Railway Station (30 km away).
      • Bus and taxi services available.

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Ozar Temple

      Overview
      Ozar Temple, located in Pune District, Maharashtra, India, is a revered Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Vigneshwar, the elephant-headed god Ganesha.

      Location
      Ozar, Pune District, Maharashtra
      Temple Timming
      • Timing:6:00 AM to 9:00 PM
      Places to explore
      • Ozar Temple: Main temple dedicated to Lord Vigneshwar
      • Lenyadri Caves: Ancient Buddhist caves (10 km)
      • Shivneri Fort: Birthplace of Shivaji Maharaj (20 km)
      • Junnar Caves: Ancient Buddhist caves (30 km)
      • Pune City: Cultural and historical attractions (85 km)
      Things to do
      • Darshan: Seek blessings from Lord Vigneshwar
      • Temple Tour: Explore the temple's architecture and history
      • Trekking: Explore nearby hills and forests
      • Local Cuisine: Try traditional Maharashtrian food
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Festivals and Events
      • Ganesh Chaturthi (August/September)
      • Vinayaka Chaturthi (September/October)
      • Mahashivratri (February/March)
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      How to Reach
      • By Road: Pune-Ozar Road (85 km)
      • By Train: Pune-Junnar Train (60 km)
      • By Air: Pune Airport (85 km)

      ISKCON Temple

      ISKCON Juhu is a renowned spiritual center, dedicated to Lord Krishna. The temple complex offers a serene atmosphere, beautiful architecture, and vibrant cultural activities.

      Location
      Sri Sri Radha Rasabihari Ji Temple, Hare Krishna Land, Juhu, Mumbai, Maharashtra, India
      Attractions
      • Beautiful temple architecture
      • Darshan (viewing) of Radha Rasabihari
      • Spiritual discourses and lectures
      • Cultural programs (music, dance, drama)
      • Vegetarian restaurant (Govinda's)
      Rituals and Events
      • Mangal Aarti (morning prayer)
      • Darshan Aarti (evening prayer)
      • Bhagavad Gita lectures
      • Krishna Janmashtami celebrations
      Tips and Essentials
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February (cool climate)
      • Timings: 9 am to 5 pm
      • Entrance Fee: ₹50 (approx.)
      • Guide Services: Available for hire
      • Safety: Follow instructions from local guides and authorities
      How to Reach
      • Nearest railway station: Vile Parle
      • Bus: Various routes connecting to Juhu
      • Auto-rickshaw/ Taxi: Available from across the city

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Shree Vighnahar Ganpati Temple

      Overview
      Dedicated to Lord Ganesha, this temple is one of the eight revered Ashtavinayak temples in Maharashtra.

      History
      Built in 1733, the temple has undergone several renovations.
      Architecture
      The temple features a beautiful blend of Peshwa and Maratha architectural styles.
      Tips and Precautions
      • Wear modest clothing.
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Follow temple rules and traditions
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Stay hydrated
      Nearby Attractions
      • Lenyadri Ashtavinayak Temple
      • Shivneri Fort
      • Pune City
      How to Reach
      The temple is approximately 85 km from Pune city and 200 km from Mumbai.
      Festivals
      Ganesh Chaturthi and Ganesh Jayanti are celebrated with great fervor.

      Dagdusheth Ganpati temple

      Overview
      The Dagadusheth Halwai Ganapati temple is a Hindu Temple located in Pune and is dedicated to the Hindu god Ganesh. The temple is visited by over one hundred thousand pilgrims every year.

      Location
      Shukrawar Peth, Pune, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      Timings: 6:00 AM to 10:00 PM
      History
      Built in 1893
      Attractions
      • 7.5 feet tall, 4 feet wide Ganesha idol
      • Beautiful murals and carvings
      • Smaller shrines and garden
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Festivals
      • Ganesh Chaturthi (main festival)
      • Ganesh Jayanti
      • Vinayaka Chaturthi
      Nearby Attractions
      • Shaniwar Wada
      • Pune Vishrambaug Wada
      • Lal Mahal
      Accommodation & Dining
      • Hotels and lodges available in Pune
      • Local Maharashtrian cuisine
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      How to Reach
      • Air: Pune Airport (12 km)
      • Rail: Pune Railway Station (4 km)
      • Road: Well-connected to major Maharashtra cities

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Harishchandreshwar Temple

      Overview
      Harishchandreshwar Temple is an ancient Shiva temple situated within Shivneri Fort in Maharashtra, India. It's a significant pilgrimage site and historical landmark, attracting devotees and tourists alike.

      Location
      The temple is situated in Shivneri Fort, Junnar, Pune District, Maharashtra, India.
      History
      Built in the 16th century, the temple has historical significance as it's linked to Shivaji Maharaj's birthplace.
      Timming
      The temple is open from 6:00 AM to 7:00 PM.
      Nearby Attractions
      • Shivneri Fort (where Shivaji Maharaj was born)
      • Lenyadri Ashtavinayak Temple
      • Ozar Vignahar Ganpati Temple
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • Maha Shivratri
      • Shivaji Jayanti
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Pune Airport (90 km)
      • By Rail: Pune Railway Station (90 km)
      • By Road: Junnar (45 km)

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Kunkeshwar Temple

      Overview
      This beautiful temple near the beach has alluring architecture reminiscent of South Indian style of temple architecture. The Yadav Kings built this temple in 1100 A. D. Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj who rejuvenated this temple many times was a frequent visitor to this temple.

      Location
      Kunkeshwar, Devgad Taluka, Sindhudurg District, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      Timings: 6:00 AM to 7:00 PM
      History
      Built in 11th century, renovated in 17th century
      Attractions
      • Beautiful Shiva Linga
      • Stunning beach views
      • Sculptures and carvings
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • Maha Shivratri
      • Ganesh Chaturthi
      • Navratri
      Nearby Attractions
      • Devgad Fort
      • Devgad Beach
      • Sindhudurg Fort
      Accommodation & Dining
      • Hotels and lodges available in Pune
      • Local Maharashtrian cuisine
      How to Reach
      • Air: Goa Airport (140 km)
      • Rail: Kankavli Railway Station (50 km)
      • Road: Devgad (30 km)

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Marleshwar Temple

      Overview
      Marleshwar is very much popular for the Cave Shiva Temple where one can see venomous snakes who do not bite the devotees. This has resulted in increasing faith in the place and every year thousands of devotees visit the place and perform ablutions in the nearby Bav river.

      Location
      Marleshwar, Sangameshwar, Ratnagiri District, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      Timings: 6:00 AM to 7:00 PM
      History
      Built in 13th century
      Attractions
      • Beautiful Shiva Linga
      • Stunning beach views
      • Sculptures and carvings
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • Maha Shivratri
      • Ganesh Chaturthi
      • Navratri
      Nearby Attractions
      • Dhareshwar Waterfall
      • Sangameshwar Temple
      • Ratnagiri Fort
      Accommodation & Dining
      • Hotels and lodges available in Pune
      • Local Maharashtrian cuisine
      How to Reach
      • Air: Ratnagiri Airport (60 km)
      • Rail: Sangameshwar Railway Station (20 km)
      • Road: Sangameshwar - Marleshwar Road

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Jyotiba Temple

      Overview
      Jyotiba Temple is a holy site of Hinduism near Wadi Ratnagiri in Kolhapur district of Maharashtra state in western India. The deity of the temple is known by the same name. An annual fair takes place on the full moon night of the Hindu months of Chaitra and Vaishakha.

      Location
      Wadi Ratnagiri, Kolhapur, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      6:00 AM to 9:00 PM
      History
      Built in 1730 by Navajisaya
      Attractions
      • 75-foot tall Jyotiba idol
      • Beautifully crafted temple complex
      • Scenic views of surrounding hills
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • Jyotiba Yatra (annual fair)
      • Maha Shivratri
      • Navratri
      Nearby Attractions
      • Mahalaxmi Temple
      • New Palace
      • Rankala Lake
      Accommodation & Dining
      • Hotels and lodges available in Pune
      • Local Maharashtrian cuisine
      How to Reach
      • Air: Kolhapur Airport (27 km)
      • Rail: Kolhapur Railway Station (22 km)
      • Road: Well-connected to major Maharashtra cities

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Saptashrungi Mata Temple

      Overview
      The temple is also known popularly as one of the "three and half Shakti Peethas" of Maharashtra. The temple is also one among the 51 Shakti Peethas located on the Indian subcontinent.

      Location
      Vani, Nashik District, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      6:00 AM to 7:00 PM
      History
      Built in 10th century
      Attractions
      • 10-foot tall Saptashrungi idol
      • Stunning natural surroundings
      • Scenic views of surrounding hills
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • Navratri (main festival)
      • Dussehra
      • Chaitra Navratri
      Nearby Attractions
      • Nashik City
      • Trimbakeshwar Shiva Temple
      • Vani Saptashrungi Gad
      Accommodation & Dining
      • Hotels and lodges available in Pune
      • Local Maharashtrian cuisine
      How to Reach
      • Air: Nashik Airport (60 km)
      • Rail: Nashik Railway Station (50 km)
      • Road: Well-connected to major Maharashtra cities

      Mahalaxmi Temple

      Overview
      Mahalakshmi Temple (also known as Ambabai Mandir) is an important Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Mahalakshmi, who resides here as Supreme Mother Mahalakshmi and is worshiped by locals as Ambabai.

      Location
      Kolhapur, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      5:00 AM to 10:00 PM
      History
      Built in 7th century
      Attractions
      • 5-foot tall Mahalaxmi idol
      • Stunning natural surroundings
      • Scenic views of surrounding hills
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      festivals
      • Navratri (main festival)
      • Dussehra
      • Kiran Utsav
      Nearby Attractions
      • New Palace
      • Rankala Lake
      • Panhala Fort
      Accommodation & Dining
      • Hotels and lodges available in Pune
      • Local Maharashtrian cuisine
      How to Reach
      • Air: Kolhapur Airport (6 km)
      • Rail: Kolhapur Railway Station (4 km)
      • Road: Well-connected to major Maharashtra cities

      Page no: 3/4

      Previous Next

      Kailasa Temple

      Overview
      The Kailasa temple (Cave 16) is the largest of the 34 Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain cave temples and monasteries known collectively as the Ellora Caves.

      Location
      Ellora Caves, Aurangabad, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      5:00 AM to 10:00 PM
      History
      Built in 8th century (756-777 AD)
      Attractions
      • 30-meter tall Shiva Linga
      • Stunning sculptures of gods, goddesses, and mythological creatures
      • Intricate carvings on walls and ceilings
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • Maha Shivratri (main festival)
      • Ganesh Chaturthi
      • Navratri
      Nearby Attractions
      • Ajanta Caves
      • Daulatabad Fort
      • Bibi ka Maqbara
      Accommodation & Dining
      • Hotels and lodges available in Pune
      • Local Maharashtrian cuisine
      How to Reach
      • Air: Aurangabad Airport (28 km)
      • Rail: Aurangabad Railway Station (30 km)
      • Road: Aurangabad - Ellora Road

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Renuka Mata, Mahurgad

      Overview
      Mahur has a sacred temple to Renuka Mata, which is considered one of the three and half Shakti Peethas (temples) in the state.

      Location
      Mahur, Nanded District, Maharashtra, India
      Temple Timming
      6:00 AM to 8:00 PM
      History
      Built in 12th century
      Attractions
      • 6-foot tall Renuka Mata idol
      • Stunning natural surroundings
      • Scenic views of surrounding hills
      Tourist Information
      • Best Time to Visit: October to February
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple

      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple

      Jhulelal Mandir Bhawan

      Overview
      Jhulelal Mandir Bhawan in Nanded, Maharashtra, is a sacred Hindu temple dedicated to Saint Jhulelal.

      Location
      Jhulelal Mandir Road, Near Hazur Sahib Gurdwara, Nanded,Maharashtra.
      History
      Built in 2001 by Sindhi community
      Attractions
      • Modern temple architecture with intricate carvings
      • Idol of Jhulelal
      • Colorful frescoes depicting Jhulelal's life
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Plan your visit according to temple timings
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • NCheti Chand (Sindhi New Year)
      • Jhulelal Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Shab-e-Barat (Night of Forgiveness)
      Nearby Attractions
      • Mahur Fort
      • Shri Renuka Devi Temple
      • Hazur Sahib Gurudwara
      Accommodation & Dining
      • Hotels and lodges available in Pune
      • Local Maharashtrian cuisine
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Nearest airport is Nanded Airport (NDC)
      • By Train: Nearest railway station is Nanded Railway Station
      • By Road: Accessible via NH 361 and MH SH 367

      Bhau Parsram Jhulelal Mandir

      Overview
      Bhau Parsram Jhulelal Mandir in Ulhasnagar, Maharashtra, is a prominent Hindu temple dedicated to Saint Jhulelal.

      Location
      Jhulelal Mandir Road, Near Ulhasnagar Railway Station, Ulhasnagar
      History
      Built in 1965 by Bhau Parsram, a Sindhi saint
      Architecture & Features
      • Colorful temple with intricate carvings
      • Idol of Jhulelal
      • EFrescoes depicting Jhulelal's life
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • NCheti Chand (Sindhi New Year)
      • Jhulelal Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Shab-e-Barat (Night of Forgiveness)
      Nearby Attractions
      • Ulhasnagar Railway Station
      • Kalyan-Dombivli
      • Ambernath
      Additional Information
      • Temple Trust: Bhau Parsram Jhulelal Mandir Trust
      • Temple Committee: Managing Committee, Bhau Parsram Jhulelal Mandir
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Nearest airport is Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (BOM)
      • By Train: Nearest railway station is Ulhasnagar Railway Station
      • By Road: Accessible via NH 48 and MH SH 367

      Gurudwara Guru Nanak Darbar

      Overview
      Gurudwara Guru Nanak Darbar in Mumbai is a beautiful and serene place to visit. This stunning white Gurudwara is adorned with a vibrant red carpet on its steps.

      Location
      Gurudwara Guru Nanak Darbar, Near Chakala Circle, Andheri Kurla Road, Andheri East, Mumbai.
      History
      Built in 1965 by Bhau Parsram, a Sindhi saint
      Architecture & Features
      • Colorful temple with intricate carvings
      • Idol of Jhulelal
      • EFrescoes depicting Jhulelal's life
      Timings
      • Morning: 5:00 AM to 12:00 PM
      • Evening: 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • Guru Nanak Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Jhulelal Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Shab-e-Barat (Night of Forgiveness)
      Nearby Attractions
      • Andheri Kurla Road
      • Chakala Circle
      • Powai Lake
      Additional Information
      • Temple Trust: Bhau Parsram Jhulelal Mandir Trust
      • Temple Committee: Managing Committee, Bhau Parsram Jhulelal Mandir
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Mumbai International Airport (10 km)
      • By Train: Andheri Railway Station (5 km)
      • By Metro: Andheri Metro Station (3 km)

      Gurudwara Shri Guru Singh Sabha

      Overview
      Gurudwara Shri Guru Singh Sabha in Pune is a revered Sikh pilgrimage site.

      Location
      Plot No 22/23, Camp Area, Pune
      History
      Established in 1925 by Sikh community
      Architecture & Features
      • Beautiful white marble structure
      • Impressive dome and intricate carvings
      • Gurudwara complex includes Guru Nanak High School
      Daily Programs
      • Morning Nitnem (prayers): 5:00 AM
      • Sukhmani Sahib (prayers): 7:00 AM
      • Langar service: 12:00 PM to 2:00 PM
      Timings
      • Morning: 5:00 AM to 12:00 PM
      • Evening: 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering the temple
      • Be cautious of crowds during festivals
      Festivals
      • Guru Nanak Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Guru Gobind Singh Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Kirtans and lectures
      Nearby Attractions
      • Pune Cantonment Area
      • Camp Area shopping
      • Pune-Okhay Railway Station
      Accommodation Options
      • Gurudwara-run accommodation: Guru Nanak Niwas
      • Private hotels: Hotel Sriman, Hotel Rajmandir, and more
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Pune Airport (10 km)
      • By Train: Pune Railway Station (5 km)
      • By Bus: Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mandal Ltd (PMPML) buses

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Gurudwara Shri Nanak Jhira

      Overview
      Gurudwara Shri Nanak Jhira in Nanded, Maharashtra, is a revered Sikh pilgrimage site.

      Location
      Wadi, Nanded, Maharashtra
      History
      Built in 1970
      Architecture & Features
      • Beautiful white marble structure
      • Impressive dome and intricate carvings
      • Langar hall (community kitchen)
      Daily Programs
      • Morning Nitnem (prayers): 5:00 AM
      • Sukhmani Sahib (prayers): 7:00 AM
      • Langar service: 12:00 PM to 2:00 PM
      Best Time to Visit
      • October to March (cool weather)
      • Avoid visiting during peak summer months (April to June)
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering
      • Respect langar and prayer services
      Festivals
      • Guru Nanak Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Guru Gobind Singh Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Kirtans and lectures
      Nearby Attractions
      • Takht Sri Hazur Sahib (2 km)
      • Sachkhand Gurudwara (2 km)
      • Hotel-Dongargaon Wildlife Sanctuary (20 km)
      Accommodation Options
      • Gurudwara-run accommodation: Guru Nanak Niwas
      • Private hotels: Hotel Sriman, Hotel Rajmandir, and more

      • By Train: Nanded Railway Station (2 km)

      Redi Ganpati

      Overview
      Redi Ganpati, located in the Sindhudurg district of Maharashtra, is a revered temple and popular tourist destination.

      Location
      Redi, Vengurla, Sindhudurg, Maharashtra
      History
      Ancient Shiva temple, believed to be over 1,000 years old
      Architecture & Features
      • Beautifully carved stone structure
      • Impressive Shikhara (tower)
      • Sacred Ganpati idol
      Daily Programs
      • Morning Abhishekam (ritual): 7:00 AM
      • Evening Aarti (prayers): 7:00 PM
      • Special pujas and festivals
      Best Time to Visit
      • October to March (cool weather)
      • Avoid visiting during peak summer months (April to June)
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering
      • Respect langar and prayer services
      Festivals
      • Ganesh Chaturthi (birth anniversary)
      • Vinayaka Chaturthi
      • Maghi Ganpati Festival
      Nearby Attractions
      • Vengurla Beach (5 km)
      • Sindhudurg Fort (15 km)
      • Tarkarli Beach (25 km)
      Accommodation Options
      • Temple-run accommodation: Dharmashala
      • Private hotels: Hotel Sagar Kinara, Hotel Vengurla Beach, and more
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Dabolim Airport, Goa (120 km)
      • By Train: Kudal Railway Station (45 km)
      • By Bus: MSRTC buses from major Maharashtra cities

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Vajreshwari Temple

      Overview
      Vajreshwari Temple, located in Vajreshwari, Maharashtra, is a revered Hindu temple and popular tourist destination.

      Location
      Vajreshwari, Thane, Maharashtra
      History
      Ancient temple, believed to be over 1,500 years old
      Architecture & Features
      • Beautifully carved stone structure
      • Impressive Shikhara (tower)
      • Hot water springs
      Daily Programs
      • Morning Abhishekam (ritual): 7:00 AM
      • Evening Aarti (prayers): 7:00 PM
      • Special pujas and festivals
      Best Time to Visit
      • October to March (cool weather)
      • Avoid visiting during peak summer months (April to June)
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering
      • Respect langar and prayer services
      Festivals
      • Navratri celebrations
      • Makar Sankranti
      • Ganesh Chaturthi
      Nearby Attractions
      • Vajreshwari Hot Water Springs (adjacent)
      • Ganeshpuri Temple (5 km)
      • Akloli Temple (10 km)
      Accommodation Options
      • Temple-run accommodation: Dharmashala
      • Private hotels: Hotel Vajreshwari, Hotel Ganeshpuri, and more
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport, Mumbai (60 km)
      • By Train: Vasai Railway Station (25 km)
      • By Bus: MSRTC buses from major Maharashtra cities

      Page no: 3/4

      Detailed View :

      Previous Next

      Swaminarayan temple

      Overview
      Swaminarayan Temple in Mumbai, also known as Shri Swaminarayan Mandir, is a beautiful Hindu temple complex located in the heart of Mumbai.

      Location
      Bhuleshwar, Mumbai, Maharashtra
      History
      Inaugurated in 1903
      Architecture & Features
      • Beautiful stone structure with intricate carvings
      • Stunning marble floors and walls
      • Colorful glasswork and stained glass windows
      Daily Programs
      • Morning Aarti (prayers): 7:00 AM
      • Evening Aarti (prayers): 7:00 PM
      • Special pujas and festivals
      Best Time to Visit
      • October to March (cool weather)
      • Avoid visiting during peak summer months (April to June)
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering
      • Respect langar and prayer services
      Festivals
      • Janmashtami (Krishna's birth anniversary)
      • Diwali (Festival of Lights)
      • Navratri celebrations
      Nearby Attractions
      • Gateway of India (3 km)
      • Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya (3 km)
      • Marine Drive (4 km)
      Accommodation Options
      • Temple-run accommodation: Dharmashala
      • Private hotels: Hotel Vajreshwari, Hotel Ganeshpuri, and more
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport (20 km)
      • By Train: Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus (3 km)
      • y Bus: BEST buses from various Mumbai locations

      Shri Swami Samarth Mandir, Akkalkot

      Overview
      Shri Swami Samarth Mandir, located in Akkalkot, Maharashtra, is a revered Hindu pilgrimage site and temple complex.

      Location
      Akkalkot, Solapur District, Maharashtra
      History
      Shri Swami Samarth (1870-1878) was a revered saint and incarnation of Lord Dattatreya
      Architecture & Features
      • Beautiful temple complex with marble floors and walls
      • Stunning idol of Shri Swami Samarth
      • Samadhi (tomb) of Shri Swami Samarth
      Daily Programs
      • Morning Aarti (prayers): 6:00 AM
      • Evening Aarti (prayers): 7:00 PM
      • Special pujas and festivals
      Best Time to Visit
      • October to March (cool weather)
      • Avoid visiting during peak summer months (April to June)
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering
      • Respect langar and prayer services
      Festivals
      • Shri Swami Samarth Jayanti (birth anniversary)
      • Diwali (Festival of Lights)
      • Navratri celebrations
      Nearby Attractions
      • Akkalkot Fort (2 km)
      • Shri Dattatreya Temple (3 km)
      • Solapur City (40 km)
      Accommodation Options
      • Temple-run accommodation: Dharmashala
      • Private hotels: Hotel Vajreshwari, Hotel Ganeshpuri, and more

      Shani Shingnapur Temple

      Overview
      Shani Shingnapur Temple, located in Nevasa, Maharashtra, is a unique and revered Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Shani.

      Location
      Shingnapur, Nevasa, Ahmednagar District, Maharashtra
      History
      Ancient temple, believed to be over 500 years old
      Architecture & Features
      • Open-air platform with Lord Shani's idol
      • Beautifully carved black stone idol
      • Surrounding village with unique architecture (no doors or locks)
      Daily Programs
      • Morning Aarti (prayers): 6:00 AM
      • Evening Aarti (prayers): 7:00 PM
      • Special pujas and festivals
      Best Time to Visit
      • October to March (cool weather)
      • Avoid visiting during peak summer months (April to June)
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering
      • Respect langar and prayer services
      Festivals
      • Shani Amavasya (new moon day)
      • Diwali (Festival of Lights)
      • Navratri celebrations
      Nearby Attractions
      • Shingnapur Village (unique architecture)
      • Ahmednagar Fort (30 km)
      • Meherabad (40 km)
      Accommodation Options
      • Temple-run accommodation: Dharmashala
      • Private hotels: Hotel Shani, Hotel Shingnapur, and more
      How to Reach

      • By Train: Ahmednagar Railway Station (35 km)

      Wai Ghat and Temples

      Overview
      Wai, a town in Satara district, Maharashtra, India, is renowned for its picturesque ghats and ancient temples. Here's essential information for tourists:

      Location
      Wai, Satara district, Maharashtra
      Attractions
      • Wai Ghat viewpoint: Panoramic views of the valley
      • Menavali Ghat: Nearby scenic ghat
      • Mahabaleshwar: Famous hill station, 30 km away
      Accommodation
      • Wai: Limited options, mostly budget-friendly
      • Panchgani: Wide range of hotels and resorts
      • Mahabaleshwar: Various hotels, resorts, and homestays
      Best Time to Visit
      • October to March (cool weather)
      • Avoid visiting during peak summer months (April to June)
      Tourist Information
      • Dress Code: Modest attire (cover shoulders and knees)
      • Photography: Allowed outside, not inside the temple
      • Entry Fee: Free
      Tips and Precautions
      • Respect temple rules and traditions
      • Avoid carrying valuables
      • Remove shoes before entering
      • Respect langar and prayer services
      How to Reach
      • By Air: Pune Airport (PNQ) is 65 km away
      • By Train: Wai Railway Station
      • By Bus: MSRTC buses from major Maharashtra cities

      Gagangiri Maharaj Temple, Khopoli

      Location
      Khopoli, Raigad District, Maharashtra, India
      Attractions
      • Scenic views of surrounding hills
      • Samadhi (tomb) of Gagangiri Maharaj
      • Beautiful temple architecture
