                              Previous Next

                              Kaas Plateau

                              Overview
                              Kaas Plateau(The World Full of Flowers),also known as Kaas Pathar located in Satara District, Maharashtra, India, is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and biodiversity hotspot known for its stunning floral diversity.

                              Details
                              • Location: Kaas Plateau, Satara District, Maharashtra
                              • Distance from Mumbai: 270 km (168 miles)
                              • Distance from Pune: 130 km (80 miles)
                              • Elevation: 1,200 meters (3,937 feet) above sea level
                              • Area: 1,000 hectares (2,471 acres)

                              Places to Explore
                              • Kaas Plateau: Explore the plateau's unique flora and fauna
                              • Kaas Lake: Scenic lake with boating facilities
                              • Sajjangad Fort: Historic fort with stunning views (10 km)
                              • Thoseghar Waterfall: Scenic waterfall (20 km)
                              • Satara City: Cultural and historical attractions (30 km)

                              Things to Do
                              • Trekking: Explore the plateau's trails and scenic views
                              • Photography: Capture stunning floral and landscape images
                              • Birdwatching: Spot rare and endemic bird species
                              • Boating: Enjoy boating on Kaas Lake
                              • Nature Walks: Explore the plateau's unique ecosystem

                              Tips and Essentials
                              • Best Time to Visit: September to November (flower blooming season)
                              • Timings: 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM
                              • Entry Fee: ₹50 - ₹100
                              • Guide: Recommended to explore the plateau's unique flora and fauna
                              • Safety: Follow plateau rules and regulations

                              Festivals and Events
                              • Kaas Plateau Festival (September)
                              • Flower Blooming Season (September to November)

                              Nearby Attractions
                              • Sajjangad Fort (10 km)
                              • Thoseghar Waterfall (20 km)
                              • Satara City (30 km)
                              • Pune City (130 km)
                              • Mumbai City (270 km)

                              Additional Tips
                              • Respect local environment and flora
                              • Follow plateau rules and regulations
                              • Enjoy scenic views and unique biodiversity
                              • Try local cuisine and street food.
                              • Visit during flower blooming season for stunning views.

                              How to reach
                              • By Road: Mumbai-Pune-Satara-Kaas Road (270 km)
                              • By Train: Satara-Kaas Train (30 km)
                              • By Air: Pune Airport (130 km)

                              Accommodation Options
                              • Budget-friendly guesthouses (e.g., Kaas Plateau Guest House)
                              • Luxury hotels (e.g., The Kaas Plateau Resort)
                              • Homestays
                              • Camping options available

                              Page no: 3/4

                              Detailed View :

                              Previous Next

                              Kolad

                              Overview
                              Kolad, located in Raigad District, Maharashtra, India, is a scenic and adventure-filled destination.

                              Details
                              • Location: Kolad, Raigad District, Maharashtra
                              • Distance from Mumbai: 120 km (75 miles)
                              • Distance from Pune: 150 km (93 miles)
                              • Elevation: 50 meters (164 feet) above sea level

                              Places to Explore
                              • Kolad Beach: Scenic beach with water sports
                              • Kundalika River: White-water rafting and kayaking
                              • Tala Fort: Historic fort with stunning views (20 km)
                              • Ghosala Fort: Historic fort with stunning views (25 km)
                              • Raigad Fort: Historic fort with stunning views (40 km)

                              Things to Do
                              • Water Sports: Jet-skiing, parasailing, boating
                              • White-Water Rafting: Experience thrilling rafting on Kundalika River
                              • Kayaking: Explore Kundalika River
                              • Trekking: Explore nearby hills and forests
                              • Fishing: Try your hand at fishing in Kundalika River

                              Tips and Essentials
                              • Best Time to Visit: June to March
                              • Accommodation: Luxury resorts, budget-friendly guesthouses
                              • Food: Seafood, local Maharashtrian cuisine, street food
                              • Safety: Follow water sports and rafting guidelines
                              • Activities: Book water sports and rafting in advance

                              Festivals and Events
                              • Kolad Festival (January)
                              • Ganesh Chaturthi (August/September)
                              • Navratri Celebrations (September/October)

                              Nearby Attractions
                              • Raigad Fort (40 km)
                              • Tala Fort (20 km)
                              • Ghosala Fort (25 km)
                              • Mumbai City (120 km)
                              • Pune City (150 km)

                              Additional Tips
                              • Respect local customs and traditions
                              • Follow local guidelines for water sports
                              • Enjoy scenic views and thrilling adventures
                              • Try local seafood and Maharashtrian cuisine.
                              • Visit during festivals for unique experiences.

                              How to reach
                              • By Road: Mumbai-Panvel-Kolad Road (120 km)
                              • By Train: Kolad-Konkan Railway Station (10 km)
                              • By Air: Mumbai Airport (120 km)

                              Accommodation Options
                              • Luxury resorts (e.g., The Kolad Resort)
                              • Budget-friendly guesthouses (e.g., Kolad Guest House)
                              • Homestays
                              • Camping options available

                              Water Sports Prices
                              • Jet-skiing: ₹800 - ₹1,200
                              • Parasailing: ₹1,000 - ₹1,500
                              • Boating: ₹500 - ₹1,000
                              • White-Water Rafting: ₹1,200 - ₹1,800
                              • Kayaking: ₹800 - ₹1,200

                              Rafting Timings
                              • Morning Session: 8:00 AM - 12:00 PM
                              • Afternoon Session: 1:00 PM - 5:00 PM

                              Page no: 3/4

                              Detailed View :

                              Previous Next

                              Lonar

                              Overview
                              Lonar(the only crater in India), located in Buldhana District, Maharashtra, India, is a scenic and historically significant destination. Known to be the world's oldest meteoric crater, formed in basalt rock. It is a notified national geo-heritage site in Maharashtra.

                              Details
                              • Location: Lonar, Buldhana District, Maharashtra
                              • Distance from Mumbai: 500 km (310 miles)
                              • Distance from Pune: 410 km (255 miles)
                              • Elevation: 563 meters (1,847 feet) above sea level

                              Places to Explore
                              • Lonar Crater Lake: World's largest meteorite impact crater lake
                              • Lonar Temple: Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu
                              • Daitya Sudan Temple: Ancient temple with intricate carvings
                              • Gomukh Temple: Ancient temple with scenic views
                              • Lonar Museum: Showcase of local history and culture

                              Things to Do
                              • Boating: Enjoy boating on Lonar Crater Lake
                              • Trekking: Explore surrounding hills and forests
                              • Photography: Capture stunning lake and temple views
                              • Birdwatching: Spot rare and migratory bird species
                              • Nature Walks: Explore local flora and fauna

                              Tips and Essentials
                              • Best Time to Visit: October to February
                              • Accommodation: Budget-friendly guesthouses, luxury hotels
                              • Food: Local Maharashtrian cuisine, street food
                              • Safety: Follow boating and trekking guidelines
                              • Activities: Book boating and trekking in advance

                              Festivals and Events
                              • Lonar Festival (January)
                              • Navratri Celebrations (September/October)
                              • Ganesh Chaturthi (August/September)

                              Nearby Attractions
                              • Ajanta Caves (120 km)
                              • Ellora Caves (150 km)
                              • Aurangabad City (160 km)
                              • Mumbai City (500 km)
                              • Pune City (410 km)

                              Additional Tips
                              • Respect local customs and traditions
                              • Follow local guidelines for boating and trekking
                              • Enjoy scenic views and historical significance
                              • Try local Maharashtrian cuisine.
                              • Visit during festivals for unique experiences.

                              How to reach
                              • By Road: Mumbai-Aurangabad-Lonar Road (500 km)
                              • By Train: Jalna-Lonar Train (60 km)
                              • By Air: Aurangabad Airport (160 km)

                              Accommodation Options
                              • Budget-friendly guesthouses (e.g., Lonar Guest House)
                              • Luxury hotels (e.g., The Lonar Resort)
                              • Homestays
                              • Camping options available

                              Entry Fees
                              • Lonar Crater Lake: ₹50 - ₹100
                              • Lonar Temple: ₹20 - ₹50
                              • Daitya Sudan Temple: ₹20 - ₹50

                              Boating Prices
                              • Boat Ride: ₹100 - ₹200
                              • Sunset Cruise: ₹200 - ₹500

                              Trekking Prices
                              • Guided Trek: ₹500 - ₹1,000
                              • Self-Guided Trek: ₹200 - ₹500

                              Page no: 3/4

                              Detailed View :

                              Previous Next

                              Kamshet

                              Overview
                              Kamshet(Replica of Paradise), located in Pune District, Maharashtra, India, is a scenic hill station and popular paragliding destination.

                              Details
                              • Location: Kamshet, Pune District, Maharashtra
                              • Distance from Mumbai: 110 km (68 miles)
                              • Distance from Pune: 45 km (28 miles)
                              • Elevation: 700 meters (2,300 feet) above sea level

                              Places to Explore
                              • Kamshet Paragliding Site: Experience thrilling paragliding
                              • Pawna Lake: Scenic lake with boating facilities
                              • Tikona Fort: Historic fort with stunning views (20 km)
                              • Lohgad Fort: Historic fort with stunning views (25 km)
                              • Bedse Caves: Ancient Buddhist caves (30 km)

                              Things to Do
                              • Paragliding: Experience thrilling paragliding
                              • Boating: Enjoy boating on Pawna Lake
                              • Trekking: Explore nearby hills and forests
                              • Photography: Capture stunning views and sunsets
                              • Nature Walks: Explore local flora and fauna

                              Tips and Essentials
                              • Best Time to Visit: October to May
                              • Accommodation: Budget-friendly guesthouses, luxury resorts
                              • Food: Local Maharashtrian cuisine, street food
                              • Safety: Follow paragliding and trekking guidelines
                              • Activities: Book paragliding and boating in advance

                              Festivals and Events
                              • Kamshet Paragliding Festival (January)
                              • Pawna Lake Festival (February)
                              • Navratri Celebrations (September/October)

                              Nearby Attractions
                              • Pune City (45 km)
                              • Mumbai City (110 km)
                              • Lonavala (50 km)
                              • Khandala (60 km)
                              • Maval (70 km)

                              Additional Tips
                              • Respect local customs and traditions
                              • Follow local guidelines for paragliding and trekking
                              • Enjoy scenic views and thrilling adventures
                              • Try local Maharashtrian cuisine.
                              • Visit during festivals for unique experiences.

                              How to reach there
                              • By Road: Mumbai-Pune-Kamshet Road (110 km)
                              • By Train: Pune-Kamshet Train (45 km)
                              • By Air: Pune Airport (45 km)

                              Accommodation Options
                              • Budget-friendly guesthouses (e.g., Kamshet Guest House)
                              • Luxury resorts (e.g., The Kamshet Resort)
                              • Homestays
                              • Camping options available

                              Paragliding Prices
                              • Tandem Paragliding: ₹2,500 - ₹4,000
                              • Solo Paragliding: ₹5,000 - ₹10,000

                              Boating Prices
                              • Boat Ride: ₹500 - ₹1,000
                              • Sunset Cruise: ₹1,000 - ₹2,000

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Rajabai Clock Tower

                              The tower was built in a fusion of Venetian and Gothic styles. It is built out of the locally available buff coloured Kurla stone. The tower has one of the best stained glass windows in the city. Council Building of the University of Mumbai in India, around 1905 The ground floor has two side rooms, each measuring 56 ft × 27.5 ft (17.1 m × 8.4 m). The tower forms a carriage porch 2.4 m2 (26 sq ft), and a spiral staircase vestibule of 2.6 m2 (28 sq ft). The Tower, over the carriage porch, has a square form up to the gallery at the top of the first level which is at a height of 68 feet (21 m) from the ground. The form changes from a square to an octagon and the height from this gallery to the top of the tower is 118 feet (36 m) and the third stage to the top of the finial is 94 feet (29 m), thus making a total height of 280 feet (85 m). During its time, it was the tallest structure in the city of Mumbai.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Hanging Garden

                              The Hanging Gardens, in Mumbai, also known as Pherozeshah Mehta Gardens, are terraced gardens perched at the top of Malabar Hill, on its western side, just opposite the Kamala Nehru Park. They provide sunset views over the Arabian Sea and feature numerous hedges carved into the shapes of animals. The park was designed and laid out in 1881 by Ulhas Ghatkopar over Bombay's main reservoir, some say to cover the water from the potentially contaminating activity of the nearby Towers of Silence. When seen from the air, the walkway inside the park (Hanging Gardens Path), spell out the letters PMG (Pherozeshah Mehta Gardens) in cursive.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Nehru Science Center

                              Nehru Science Centre, the largest Science Centre in the country has a sprawling 8 acres (32,000 m2) of science park with varieties of plants, trees and shrubs. More than 500 hands-on and interactive science exhibits on energy, sound, kinematics, mechanics, transport, etc. are installed in the park. The NSC building, with its unique architecture, houses several permanent science expositions on various theme. National Council of Science Museums (NCSM), the parent body of Nehru Science Centre, Mumbai, with its 25 science centres / museums all over the country, has the best infrastructure and skilled manpower to conceptualise, design, develop and organise high quality science exhibits and other related educational programmes and activities. The centre is one of the four national level science museums in NCSM, working as the Western Zone Headquarters with five science centres in Nagpur, Calicut, Bhopal, Dharampur and Goa under its umbrella, caters to the people in the Western part of India. As a part of its activities, the centre organises regular extensive science education programmes, activities and competitions for the benefit of the common people and students in particular.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya

                              Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya, Mumbai's iconic cultural institution, showcases India's rich artistic and historical heritage, spanning over 5,000 years. Established in 1905, this premier museum boasts an impressive collection of over 50,000 artifacts, including Indian miniature paintings, European art, sculptures, textiles, decorative arts, and artifacts from ancient India, including the Indus Valley Civilization. The museum's galleries, such as the Indian miniature paintings gallery, European painting gallery, and sculpture gallery, offer a glimpse into the country's diverse cultural influences. Visitors can explore an extensive collection of artifacts, including ancient Indian coins, jewelry, and arms and armor. With its stunning architecture, beautiful gardens, and engaging exhibitions, CSMVS attracts art enthusiasts, historians, and tourists alike. The museum's educational programs, workshops, and lectures promote cultural awareness and preservation. Open daily from 10:00 AM to 6:00 PM, this treasured institution is a testament to India's vibrant cultural legacy, providing an enriching experience for visitors of all ages. Located in the heart of Mumbai, CSMVS is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in exploring India's rich cultural heritage.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Essel World

                              EsselWorld is an amusement park located in Gorai on Dharavi island, Mumbai. It is operated Pan India Pariyatan Ltd. It covers an area of 65 acres along with Water Kingdom, and was opened to the public in 1989. Along with Adlabs Imagica, EsselWorld is one of the largest amusement parks in India.The park's catchphrase is "EsselWorld me rahunga mein, ghar nahi jaunga mein ", which means "I will stay in EsselWorld, and do not want to go home". The amusement parks industry in India is nascent (it’s a 60-year-old industry in the West). And yet, it is evolving and diversifying very rapidly.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Bandra Bandstand

                              The Bandstand Promenade, also known as Bandra Bandstand is a 1.2 kilometer long walkway along the sea on the western coast of Mumbai, India in the neighborhood of Bandra. It is simultaneously a popular hangout spot, a jogging track and a park. Towards the Land's End side of the promenade is an amphitheater. It serves as a venue for the Mumbai Festival, Celebrate Bandra and other events including concerts, classical dance and other performances.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Bandra-Worli Sea Link

                              The largest pylons for the bridge consist of diamond shaped 128 metres (420 ft) high concrete tower featuring flaring lower legs, converging upper legs, a unified tower head housing the stays and a continuously varying cross section along the height of tower. The bridge's pylon towers gradually decrease in cross-section with height. They have horizontal grooves every 3m in height, which permitted inserts. Vertical grooves in the circular sections require special form liners, as well as require attention for de-shuttering. The tower legs are inclined in two directions, which presented challenges in alignment and climbing of soldiers. Construction joints were permitted at 3m intervals only. To build the pylons, Doka of Austria was commissioned to build a custom automatic climbing shutter formwork system, based on their SKE-100 automatic climbing shutter system. This was fabricated on site and employed to execute all tower leg lifts below deck level.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Marine Drive

                              Most of the buildings erected by wealthy Parsis were constructed in an art deco style, which was popular in the 1920s and 1930s. Among the earliest art deco buildings on Marine Drive were the Kapur Mahal, Zaver Mahal and Keval Mahal, built between 1937 and 1939 for a total cost of 1 million rupees. Real estate prices along the esplanade are high. Many hotels dot the drive, most prominent among them being the 5-star Oberoi (formerly the Oberoi Hilton Tower however reverted to the original name as of early 2008), The Intercontinental, Hotel Marine Plaza, Sea Green Hotel and a few smaller hotels. Marine Drive is the preferred connecting road between the central business district located at Nariman Point and the rest of the city. Many sports clubs, some cricket stadiums and club grounds are situated along the stretch of Marine Drive, including members-only clubs like the Cricket Club of India (CCI), adjoining the Brabourne Stadium, Hindu Gymkhana Ground and Garware Club House, adjacent to the famous Wankhede Stadium, as well as others like the Mumbai Police Gymkhana, Hindu Gymkhana, Parsi Gymkhana and Islam Gymkhana.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Govardhan Eco Village

                              Govardhan Eco Village, nestled in Wada, Maharashtra, is a tranquil oasis showcasing sustainable living and spiritual growth. Spanning 85 acres, this eco-friendly village seamlessly blends traditional Indian architecture with modern amenities. The village is centered around organic farms, cow shelters, and rural activities, offering visitors an immersive experience of rural India. Guests can participate in yoga and meditation sessions, guided farm tours, and interactive workshops on sustainable living. The village promotes environmental conservation, social responsibility, and community engagement. Explore the on-site Ayurvedic center, herbal garden, and artisan village, showcasing local craftsmanship. Accommodations range from deluxe rooms to eco-friendly cottages, crafted from natural materials. Savor wholesome, vegetarian cuisine prepared using fresh, organic produce from the village farms. Govardhan Eco Village serves as a retreat for those seeking solitude, spiritual growth, and connection with nature.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Saras Baug

                              Saras Baug, located in the heart of Pune, Maharashtra, is a picturesque and serene destination that showcases nature's beauty. Spread over 25 acres, this stunning garden was built in 1830 and features a beautiful lake, walking trails, lush greenery, and well-manicured lawns. Initially known as "Peshwe Udyan" during the Peshwa rule, it was later renovated and transformed into a beautiful garden. Visitors can enjoy boating facilities on the lake, stroll along the walking trails, or simply relax in the peaceful surroundings. The garden also offers picnic spots, food stalls, and restaurants, making it an ideal spot for families and nature lovers. The garden is open from 6:00 AM to 9:00 PM from April to September and from 6:00 AM to 8:00 PM from October to March. Entry fees are nominal, with adults paying ₹10, children between 5-12 years paying ₹5, and children below 5 years entering for free. Located near Swami Dayanand Saraswati Math, Pune, Maharashtra 411030, Saras Baug is easily accessible. Whether seeking relaxation, recreation, or quality time with family, Saras Baug is a must-visit destination in Pune, offering a tranquil atmosphere and beautiful landscapes that leave visitors enchanted.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Rock Garden

                              Rock Garden, Malvan, is a stunning coastal destination showcasing natural beauty and artistic creativity. Located on the Arabian Sea coastline, this picturesque garden is crafted from laterite rocks, spread over 2 acres. Intricately designed rock formations blend seamlessly with the surrounding landscape, offering breathtaking views of the sea. Visitors can relax in the serene atmosphere, stroll along the coastline, and enjoy stunning sunsets, making it a photographer's paradise. The garden features beautiful gardens, lawns, and a coastal walking path, perfect for leisurely strolls. Local artisan shops nearby showcase Malvan's rich cultural heritage. Open from 9:00 AM to 7:00 PM, the garden welcomes visitors with nominal entry fees: ₹20 for adults, ₹10 for children (5-12 years), and free for children below 5 years. Located near Malvan Beach, Maharashtra 416606, Rock Garden is easily accessible. Whether seeking relaxation, inspiration, or quality time with family, Rock Garden, Malvan, is a must-visit destination. Its unique blend of natural beauty and artistic expression makes it an unforgettable experience amidst the Arabian Sea's splendor.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Kaas Plateau

                              The Kaas Plateau Reserved Forest, also known as the Kaas Pathar, is a plateau situated 25 kilometres west from Satara city in Maharashtra, India. It falls under the Sahyadri Sub Cluster of the Western Ghats, and it became a part of a UNESCO World Natural Heritage Site in 2012. It is a biodiversity hotspot known for various types of seasonal wild flowers bloom and numerous species of endemic butterflies annually in the months of August and September. The plateau is situated at an altitude of 1200 metres and is approximately 10 square kilometers in area. Kaas has more than 850 different species of flowering plants. These include orchids, shrubs such as the Karvy, and carnivorous plants such as Drosera Indica. Kaas Pathar is a plateau made from volcanic rocks in the Satara district of Maharashtra, and comes under the biosphere of the Western Ghats. The flora of kaas i.e. the entire flowering plants and their related plants are typically restricted to that particular locality only. This is because the plateau is largely formed of basalt which is directly exposed to atmosphere. The basalt is almost covered entirely by a thin cover of soil formed due to erosion and has accumulated a layer of not more than 25 mm or so.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Kolad

                              Kolad is a village in Raigad district, Maharashtra State, India. It is 117 km from Mumbai on the National Highway no 66(Mumbai-Goa) its also connected to Pune via Kolad Pune- Kolad state highway. It lies on the banks of River Kundalika. The village post office Postal Index Number (PIN code) is 402304 & 402109. Kolad railway station is the first station on the Konkan Railway line. Express and mail trains connect Kolad to Mumbai in approximately three hours. Kolad is the starting point for the roll-on/roll-off (RORO) service of the Konkan Railway, a road-rail synergy system, where loaded trucks are directly carried by railway wagons and delivered to their destination by rail. This service was introduced in January 1999. White water river rafting is a popular adventure water sport for people from Mumbai and Pune. The Kundalika River in Kolad is the best option for white water rafting in Maharashtra. The huge amount of water released from a local dam each morning creates good opportunities for rafting. The Maharashtra government promotes river rafting through its official tourism website.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Lonar

                              Lonar is situated around 360 km from Nagpur, around 100 km from Buldhana, around 100 km from Akola, 550 km from Mumbai, around 160 km from Aurangabad and around 140 km southeast of the Ajanta Caves, about 4½ hours drive via Buldhana. Lonar town is located at 19°59′06″N 76°31′23″E. It has an average elevation of 563 m (1847 feet). As of the 2001 Indian census, Lonar had a population of 20,082. Males constitute 52% of the population and females 48%. Lonar has an average literacy rate of 66%, higher than the national average of 59.5%: male literacy is 74%, and female literacy is 58%. In Lonar, 16% of the population is under 6 years of age.

                              Page no: 4/4

                              Video Explaination:

                              Kamshet

                              Kamshet has a hot semi-arid climate (Köppen BSh) bordering a tropical savanna climate (Aw) and average temperatures ranging between 20 and 26 °C (68 and 79 °F). Kamshet experiences three seasons: summer, monsoon and a winter. Typical summer months are from March to May, with maximum temperatures ranging from 28 to 36 °C (82 to 97 °F). The warmest month in Pune is April; although summer doesn't end until May, the city often receives very heavy thundershowers in May (and humidity remains high). Even during the hottest months, the nights are usually cool due to Kamshet's high altitude. The highest temperature ever recorded was 42.3 °C (108.1 °F) on 30 April 1897. The monsoon lasts from June to October, with moderate rainfall and temperatures ranging from 21 to 27 °C (70 to 81 °F). Most of the 722 mm (28.43 in) of annual rainfall in the city fall between June and September, and July is the wettest month of the year. Hailstorms are also common in this region.
